We went here because of YELP. My party and I made reservations through Open Table for two and the restaurant even called to confirm. So we're thinking...this place must and will be amazing! As fellow Yelpers have attested to, we anticipated a fine dining experience..especially with 881 reviews and 4 1/2 stars, what could go wrong right? Well, we arrived and were seated instantly. My coat was checked and hung. Drinks (water and champagne), bread and butter were served right away. Great start. After sitting there for 10 minutes, this man, I'm not sure if he's the owner/manager/head waitress but he gave us the menus and took our order (He also took every table's order thereafter so I'm sure he's the top personnel) . We went with the early bird of $28/person and shared it family style.FOOD:1st Course: SOUP OF THE DAY (ONION SOUP)-Tasted like melted cheddar cheese and precooked yet over cooked thick onion broth. The bread at the bottom of the bowl was too soggy and had been sitting in the soup too long. TRADITIONAL ESCARGOT DE BOURGOGNE IN BUTTER-PARSLEY & GARLIC SAUCE-The butter-parsley sauce was rich and could very well resemble olive oil. The escargot was soft to the bite, excellent. 2nd Course:PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND MUSSELS STEAMED WITH WHITE WINE, SHALLOT & PARSLEY, POMMES FRITES & ROUILLE-Good but not great following the escargot. The sauce was similar to the butter-parsley & garlic sauce used with the escargot only a little more diluted. Good portion.FARM RAISED CANADIAN SALMON BRAISED FENNEL & LEEK, BACON FLAVORED FINGERLING POTATOES, SHALLOT CONFIT, SAFFRON EMULSION-Salmon was medium rare as the guy that took our order had stated, but almost crusted on the top and tasted sweet. I'm a huge fan of salmon and sake but the sweet flavor just threw my taste buds off. 3rd Course: BASIL NAPOLEON W/ MAUI PINEAPPLE, MANILLA MANGO, BANANA, KIWI & STRAWBERRIES/CHAMPAGNE-CITRUS PASTRY CREAM/ FEUILLE DE BRIQUE-Don't let the name and description fool you. It would have been a beautiful and excellent dish if it had not been for the basil flavored sauce. The basil is potent. If you get this dish, make sure you omit the sauce or get it on the side. Personally, this dish was so confusing; it'd be better served as an appetizer than dessert. It really made me wish I had chosen ice cream instead =/.TAHITIENNE VANILLA BEAN CRME BRULE, ALMOND TUILE-This made up for the Basil Napolean and reminded me why I was there in the first place...excellent. Great portion.AMBIENCE:Obviously I missed the part where it says "a French Bistro" under their restaurant name. It's true, they're a bistro with a fine dining price tag. The place is dimly lit and the tables are very close to one another. Let's just say every time I looked up from my plate, I was practically a part of the neighboring parties' table! I had to avoid eye contact so they wouldn't think otherwise. Also, be prepared for a loud dining experience as the place is small. It's pretty packed and everyone is talking too. With that said, It's not a date friendly nor romantic place. And it definitely lacked the French ambiance I was looking for, the head personnel were Asian speaking French...which is great...but the atmosphere just wasn't there...and our bus boy/waiter was Latino who didn't understand English. Just a really differently infused yet diverse place. Truth be told, I was expecting a place more like the quaint Italian restaurants off of Columbus Street in North Beach with Italian servers or fast paced Chinese waiters serving food in Chinatown. This place was just different.I always like to judge a place by its restroom...if you don't need to go, don't go. Chapeau's women's restroom (single) reeked of urine and dcor sincerely lacked for such a high-end bistro.STAFF/SERVICE: Very attentive, friendly, and fast. Considering we were seated by the kitchen and along the wall that paralleled the aisle to the kitchen, staff was rushing back and forth every other minute. That was distracting...but they never let my water glass go empty. Personally, the 1-3 star yelpers for Chapeau give a more accurate account and perception. Everyone else might have been buzzed. *This place serves wine like no other...every table had wine and the staff is excellent at refilling if you purchased a bottle! I give Chapeau 4 stars for the food and -3 stars for the service. We had a group of 4 with a reservation at 5:30 pm on Father's Day (which is considered a holiday so no prix fixe menu). Three of us ordered the 3 course meal. It took 2 hours and 45 minutes for them to serve us our dinner, and it would have taken longer if we hadn't gotten fed up after waiting 30 minutes for our dessert and asked for it to be "rushed" out. Our water glasses were also refilled very infrequently. I am a very slow drinker of anything, so it is rare for me to be shaking the last few drops of water out of my glass. I understand that the restaurant was filled to capacity, but given that most people make reservations, they should have been properly staffed.I suppose if you are looking for a true French eating experience that takes an entire evening, then go right ahead and make your reservation for Chapeau. Or just don't make any after-dinner plans like we did.
My wife and I celebrated our anniversary with a wonderful dinner at Chapeau! We went with the 3-course prix fix, having the mesclun salad, filet, and both the creme brulee and profiteroles. The service was wonderful. They gave us tastings of the wines we ordered by the glass. I was unhappy with mine and, with no annoyance, the waiter quickly brought me the wine list again, and suggested a much better wine.The filet was a perfect cut of meat, though the chef's idea of medium and medium rare is much rarer than mine. I suggest you order one step more done than you regularly do. The salad was a little sweet, needing some acid to balance it out.The creme brulee was perfection. No gimmicky fruity flavors, which chefs often use to hide the low quality of their vanilla. This was perfectly creamy, with the right amount of candied sugar.We left full, happy, and wanting to come back again.
Chapeau was the perfect choice to have an intimate dinner for two. The food was excellent, the staff knowledgable, and the ambiance was great. We chose the 3 course prix fixe menu for $38. For foie gras, I had to add $6 but I totally didn't mind. It was rich and delicious, but I only wish there was more toast. The bf got the creamy corn soup with dungeness crab and it was flavorful and really creamy. He didn't enjoy it as much as me because he thought it was too rich. Plus, they served complimentary cauliflower soup and I really wish I could have chosen the soup as my appetizer.For the entree, I got the Bacon Wrapped Natural Pork Tenderloin with Potato Puree and Spinach. The meal is as good as it sounds! The accompanying sauce was delicious and I ate every last bite of my dish even though I was stuffed. The bf got the Lamb Shank with Eggplant Couscous. He liked the lamb but didn't enjoy the eggplant couscous bc it was a bit too tangy with him. I agree, it didn't have such a pleasant taste.For dessert, the bf ordered the warm chocolate cake (takes 20 mins. to prepare) and with one bite, you could taste how moist, fluffy, and hot it was! Proceed with caution. I chose the Grand Mere Tart ... an apple custard tart with hazelnut ice cream on the side. I liked the ice cream more. One star off because I don't like how close together the tables are. I don't like listening to other's conversations and vice versa. Plus, they put some cushions on the wooden seats and rather than providing comfort, it was a nuisance. My ass was sitting on the crack of two pillows. Not cool.

Chapeau doesn't look like much from the street, but don't be fooled. This is some of the best french food in the city, at bargain prices. Not as good as La Folie, but not far off (and quite a bit cheaper). I ate there with my folks 3 months ago for my birthday, so my memory of the dishes I ate is not precise. But I do know that I had a duck breast that melted in my mouth and an unbelievable chocolate fondant for dessert. The service was attentive and unpretentious. Don't expect the orchestrated ballet of Michael Mina or Gary Danko -- Chapeau is far too informal for that. Chef Phillipe Gardelle makes a point to introduce himself to every table; charming and gracious, he makes you feel at home (he kissed my mom on both cheeks as we were leaving, which always delights her, as she is one of the biggest Francophiles you will ever meet). This was the first what will surely be many visits.

OK, let me start at the beginning, and confess that I've been coming to Chapeau! and have known Philippe and Elaine Gardelle since their son would appear in the restaurant wearing a cowboy shirt, a two-gallon hat (he was little) and a pair of toy six-guns wrapped around his waist . . . (boy, is he going to be embarassed if he ever reads this!) . . . Philippe and Elaine have seen me through two different jobs, a couple of girlfriends (before my wife -- shhhhh!), a couple of knee operations, my marriage*, and who know what else since they have opened.Since they have opened, I have probably dined there some three -- maybe even four -- DOZEN times, and I can honestly say I have NEVER had anything less than an excellent meal there. And since I moved out of The City and into Berkeley, we still drive over the bridge and into the Richmond to have dinner there on a "regular-but-not-as-often-as-we'd-like" basis.Our kids love it. Our friends love it. I've been there with everything from a party of two to a party of 16 (OK, that WAS a bit tight), and worn everything from blue jeans and a nice sweater to a suit-and-tie. I've always felt comfortable, as if I were dining in Philippe & Elaine's home, and every meal has been memorable.Every city has its "big name" restaurants -- places like Gary Danko's or Chez Panisse -- Chapeau! is not a Michelin three-star type restaurant. But it gets five stars here because, in its category, there is no better choice than Chapeau! As others have noted already, the prix fixe menu is the way to go. The cassoulet is excellent, the French onion soup awesome, every item on the menu is delicious -- the meals here are the only ones I've had in California that remind me of dining in France -- solid, excellent, reliable "comfort" food with that extra je ne c'est quoi that speaks to me of REAL French cuisine, and not "Fancy French Food."* Lynn & I were actually going to have our wedding party dinner there, but when the wedding itself balooned from 50 to 120+ people, we outgrew Chapeau! and had to hire a caterer.
Eating here is like eating at someone's home. That may be a bit of an overstatement, but if you can put aside the fancy accoutrements and the fact that there are servers ... there is something wonderfully intimate, warm and special.When I went for my birthday last year, the highlight of my meal was the bone marrow. It came as part of the prime rib special for two, and the whole course was sumptuous. The meat was cooked beautifully, and the bone marrow was quite simply perfection. Strongly recommend!

We have been living in the city now for about 2 months and we LOVE to eat out. I mean, that's just what we do. We don't do it for the laziness of not wanting to cook at home...but more for the enjoyment of the entire dining experience. Unfortunately, every experience we have had has been sub par...just okay..or worse. Until now...Chapeau is now my absolute favorite restaurant. The entire dining experience was just that...an experience..We exited the taxi to find a drab street with a lot of sad buildings. The sign for the restaurant was a bit unbecoming..."Chapeau" scribbled in what looked like pencil on a white piece of paper and taped the front window. There was no peeking inside to see if we should run after the taxi and escape before anyone saw...the blinds were shut, and instead of a door...there was an enormous black velvet curtain for our entrance. Oh boy. We took a deep breath, opened the curtain and walked only two steps inside...what we saw was, well, weird. There we were, standing in the middle of the dining room. I had read this in other reviews but honestly thought they were exaggerating (sorry fellow yelpers, I shall never doubt you again!). The room was packed! Gussied up servers dashing around with plates of food, bottles of champagne, and desserts that made my mouth water...Tables were intimately close to the next and draped in white with simple and elegant dinnerware. The crowd was alive with conversation and laughter...a smile, I think, on everyone's face.. no pretentiousness detected here. The decor reminded me of the south...dried flower arrangements hanging on the peach painted walls. And the smell made my stomach turn suddenly with immense hunger..There was no hostess stand...no hostess to be found...All of this on a beautiful August Tuesday night...We were seated right away, although we were nearly a half an hour early for our 8:30 reservation (the only one left 2 days in advance - message here is to be sure to make a ressie). We were seated so closely to the couple next to us we could hear everything they were saying...she was a flight attendant, he was her passenger...she said she looked like lucy lu (hahaha..more like margaret cho), he told her that Cheesy was Mandarin for Crazy (dork). I digress...The menu.Oh the wonderful menu!!! I had the foie gras seared and served on brioche with peach syrup. OH MY GOD. amazing. He had the Goat Cheese Napoleon...polenta, tomatoes, goat cheese with pine nuts and zucchini...went deliciously with our glass of champagne. We chose to have palette cleansers...ya, that's right...for 4 dollars a piece you can choose from lemon ginger sorbet sitting in a citrus vodka served in a sugar rimmed martini glass, or the green apple version. We got one of each. So refreshing. We both chose the Fillet. Holy Cow. Seriously...must have been sent from heaven...I didn't even need a knife...no kidding. so delicate, soft, velvety. Get it. To finish things off, we had the cheese plate to go with our bottle of red we brought ourselves..while we waited for the chocolate molten cake. (I told you, we know how to eat). The bill came in a hat and I didn't gasp at the total for a change...Okay. Here is the moment I had been waiting for. I had read in previous reviews that the chef would chase you down the street to kiss your cheek but thought he only did that for those special pple, you know? We snuck out...no chef in sight. We stood outside for a minute, contemplating on the best place to catch a taxi...and started to walk...hmm. no chef. Was he mad because we brought our own bottle of wine...ALAS! he came running out of the restaurant, met us in the middle of the street, with no concern for his safety..kissed my cheeks and asked how everything was! I couldn't believe it! What an awesome thing to do. Smart, wonderful Chef from Chapeau...I love you...as only a girl who loves food and attention could. You kissed my boyfriend too! How cute.Summary: Make ressies.Don't worry about the money..it's not expensive, really.You can bring your own bottle of wine for an $18 corking fee, but really, the wine list is a novel.Leave your intimacy problems at home.You can wear whatever...the guy a couple of tables down was wearing sweats...no body minded....I cannot wait to go back.
Had a very nice meal here with my sister the other day.There a full bar with a few seats on one side and a small dining room on the other side. The tables are very close together. So, it's difficult to have a private conversation unless the table next to you is empty, which it was for part of the time we were there. Service is very attentive and responsive to requests. My sister and I were sharing cocktails when they started the food service. I asked the waiter to wait until we finished our cocktails before starting the meal and they complied w/o complaint.They offer a very reasonable $28 3-course "early bird special'(530-6pm) and a couple of do-it-yourself 3-4 course prix fixe offerings. The menu is not that extensive, so the early bird is really the better deal. The meal started w/an amuse buse -- a califlower soup. My sister and I chose different early bird specials, but shared a very nice faux gras appetizer to statt, which wasn't cheap at $18, but was a very nicely cooked piece of natual foie gras served on a bed of something (not sure what) along w/sliced apples and a maple syrup type sauce. Very original. For the early bird, I had the escargot appetizer (prepared traditionally w/garlic, parlsey & butter sauce) and 2 small roasted chickens. My sister had a mesclun salad and musssels for the entre. We both ate the Basil Napolean for desert - a mixture of finely minced fruit (Maui Pineapple, Manilla Mango, Banana, Kiwi & Strawberries) with a champagne/cream sauce. Everything was very well prepared and we topped if off w/a bottle of Patz & Hall pinot which was also very good. I was not familiar w/most of the California and French wines offered. We tired a sip of the by-the-glass pinot with the thought of buying a bottle for $40, but it was underwhelming. So, chose the Patz & Hall, which was the only wine I was familiar w/for $70 instead. It was a good choice. We had a very long conversation over dinner and wine and were not rushed out, which made sense since there were many empty tables after around 7pm. However, people seem attracted by the "early bird special" because the place was unusually busy the first hour or so (we arrived at 530) while we were there. So, if you're planning to take advantage of the "early bird" special, you should plan to actually get there early. My sister and I enjoyed ourselves and I definitely plan to go back soon.

Chapeau! is in the most unlikely neighborhood; it's at 15th Ave. and California in the Richmond District, and easy to miss because its front is small and looks just like any other house on its block. If you peek in the windows when the restaurant is closed, it looks like just a small cute place, not that exciting. Eating there is a whole different story! My boyfriend and I went there for his birthday; it was a weekday and we went early (6:30 pm). We ordered the prix fixe four-course dinner (it was prix fixe but a small additional amount if you chose a filet mignon). First they served bread, which was crusty outside and warm inside; super good. There was a tiny cup of a very rich cream of cauliflower soup first. I don't like cauliflower generally, but the soup was delicious! It was so delicious that I can't even say "I don't like cauliflower" anymore. Our second course was a perfect large scallop atop a rich, creamy lobster risotto. It was incredible. At some point there was a palate cleansing sorbet; we had a choice of two, and we both chose a lemon-ginger-vodka one. The other option was also a citrus-type thing.My boyfriend had sea bass, which had whipped potatoes underneath, and I had the filet mignon, which I asked for medium-well. The server, who was extremely nice, didn't snub me for it. It came out a little more on the well done side, which I think a lot of restaurants do for people who ask for medium well because they figure you're hardly going to complain that it's TOO well-done if you ordered medium-well in the first place. Even well-done, the steak was tender and delicious and pretty amazing. For dessert we had a fantastic creme brulee, and a warm chocolate cake which oozed hot chocolately filling when we broke the little cake with a fork. It came with rum raisin ice cream. The warm chocolate cake could probably bring some people to tears, it's that good. The service is very nice; the courses are very nicely timed, the place is pretty (decorated with some frilly hats, and your check is brought to you in a hat), but very small, and the tables are super close together. As night wears on, they dim the lights more and more inside, which is nice. As people drink, it gets pretty loud, and there was no music, at least on the night we went. When we got our bill, the server put the hat with the bill on the table, rather than shoving it at the man, like a lot of places do, which was nice. The clients were what you'd expect; older people early on, with younger people arriving later.
I went to Chapeau! with a small group of friends for a birthday. We all got the $27 early bird price fix menu and each of us tried something different. Everyone's dishes were incredible! The Chef, Philippe, walked around and greeted diners. Our waiter was attentive and recommended an excellent bottle of wine. The desserts were also amazing!I am a pretty plain Jane sorta girl, and can't usually "dig in" to French fare, but everything was enjoyable for the sophisticated or unsophisticated diner! I loved every bite!
Between mispronouncing words and being dumbfounded by wine lists, I am pretty humbled by fancy restaurants, so the relaxed atmosphere of Chapeau really saved the day.True that tables are close together and it's high on noise level, but Chapeau's personable service makes up for it. On top of getting courses of great food for a pre-vday vday dinner, another great thing about this place is that they offer half glasses of wine for rookies like me or for those who like to taste but not commit--plus that way your white wines stay cold!
Fine french cuisine dining in a bistro with a romantic feel and setting. Make reservations as this place is busy. Three course meal is $38, while the four course meal is $46. You would think that the prix-fixed menu portions are smaller than the entree size, but they were the same. The lamb shoulder did NOT taste like lamb. It tasted more like duck. The lamb shoulder meat was extremely tender and the skin was cooked to a perfect crisp. Came here for our first anniversary celebration. We'll probably have to wait another year to come back because we're poor college students.Food: My boyfriend praised the complimentary fish with potato salad on a spoon, he said he didn't want to swallow it because it tasted so damn good. I don't eat shellfish, so I decided to stay away from seafood in general. I'm like an opposite pescetarian. The waiter asked me why I didn't eat it and I told him, he was very nice and got me a slice of baguette with tomato sauce on it, which was wonderful. On to appetizers, I had the onion soup. It was alright, I guess since I love my mother's onion soup, it's hard to match it. I found it was a bit dull, it had no bang to the initial mouthful. Then my entree was the Cassoulet de Toulouse, it was nice, very filling. The lamb was cooked perfectly. It was still moist and kept it's flavor. But I enjoyed my boyfriend's filet mignon much more, he had it with the Sauce  la Prigourdine, and it was just indescribably good. Then for dessert I had the Banana Panna Cotta/ Strawberry Salad/ Shortbread. I think that the shortbread could of been either smaller or thinner. This reminded me of strawberry shortcake. It was wonderful none the less. I could taste the strawberry more than the banana panna cotta. Just reviewing it now, reminded me it was banana rather than strawberry panna cotta. Atmosphere: My boyfriend and I came in semiformal. Sadly there was no dress code, yes, I wished there were a loose dress code. It boosts the atmosphere. Since this seems like a very nice place. There were people coming in, in sweats and t shirts. It was very cramped in the restaurant. You would imagine a place would have quiet conversations where everyone seems to be whispering. But not this place, everyone is so close it turns into a loud hum, just below a Chinese restaurant.Service: The waiter was very nice and very personable. He had quite a thick French accent so when he was telling us the specials it was sort of hard to hear. No problems though, he was nice enough to tell us what we miss with out being irked about it. He also offered to take my coat to the coat room and at the end he held it out for me to put it back on. I'm not use to this service so I felt very awkward. He was really good with recommendations. The chef also came out and greeted everyone, shook everyone's hand and initiated conversations. He reminded me of the chef in a queen latifah movie...Last Holiday. At the end of the meal my boyfriend and I stepped out the door and the chef came out just to say goodbye to us. He shook my hand, kissed each of my cheek then shook my boyfriends hand and said hope to see you soon! For sure it's a place I would like to go back to, just when I have a bit more money.

A whole group of us got the 3-course meal for $38 apiece. We received a complimentary starter of cauliflower soup with truffle flavor - very good, clean taste. For the appetizer, I got the Trio of Salmon (gravlax, tartar, caviar) - interesting, though too salty. For the price, was surprised that the smoked salmon was chewy vs. tender. For the entree, I got the day boat scallops in lobster sauce (daily special). Scallops were underdone so the interior was still cold - I'm sure this was on purpose, but would have preferred a higher degree of doneness; however, lobster sauce was good. For wine, we got a very good 2005 Pinot Grigio, Amethyst, Reserve, Los Carneros for $38.Dessert was shared among the entire group. Vanilla bean creme brulee was disappointing - cold in the interior like most places without even the saving grace of a crispy top. Basil Napoleon was an interesting combination, but the flavors didn't quite work together. Floating Island was a piece of art with a delicate weave of hardened sugar curving over the plate. At the end of the day, the real winner (surprisingly) was the very honest French Toast - not fancy, but just done well and seared to just the right degree of brownness.Overall assessment: If you're after combinations of ingredients that aim more for uniqueness than for taste, then this is your place. Besides the Cauliflower Soup and French Toast, everything else was just ... interesting ... a good thought experiment, but nothing I'd want to have again.Parking is terrible, so come early and be ready to circle.

Chapeau! has the charm of a cozy French cafe that can only be found in your neighborhood restaurant. Michael is precise and attentive, skilled with wine pairing, and understands the needs of the patrons that frequent this establishment. The proprietors, a Caucasian man, Philip, and Asian woman (a wonderfully married couple), know exactly how to make your night one to remember and keep returning for more every year. As you enter Philips graciously greets all of the guests that enter and for any female patrons, would give the classic European double cheek air-kiss.The dining room can seat about 40-45 comfortably and there was a good diverse cross section of patrons for the night at 8:30 PM. Caucasian and Asian adult patrons were mostly in attendance.Last Saturday, they had a splendid menu prepared. The evening started with a cauliflower amuse boush to wet the appetite for the foie gras appetizer paired with warm French bread. The richness of foie gras is not to be missed and my dinner companions thoroughly enjoyed their first time of having foie gras as well as French cuisine.A flavorful butternut squash puree filled your senses and it was a wonderful compliment to the chilly San Francisco air outside. The soft orange color of the puree was perfect as it reflected the light yellow walls of Chapau! The rabbit entre was accompanied by glazed carrots, drizzled with a tangy sauce, and it only had the slight hint of the rabbit meat. This is a perfect dish for adventurous eaters, but do not want to be overwhelmed by unfamiliar senses.Drinks for the night included still bottled water, chamomile tea, a magnificent orange soup with hazelnut praline and a hint of mint, and a 2000 vintage dessert wine that effervescent in your mouth leaving a dry and satisfying taste behind for you to relish the delights of the night. For an enjoyable Saturday evening and a $45-50 meal, Chapeau! should be your first French dinner destination.

I finally dined at Chapeau after wanting to for a couple years. We went New Years Eve; 10:30 seating. I think the price was $125.00 each plus an additional $40.00 each for the wine pairing. May I say the food was superb and the wine perfectly match. Our five course meal started with a crab cake, more like a tiny crab ball but one must have crab during the New Year's holiday so I stopped laughing at it and bit into it. Delicious! Too bad it was only one bite. Next, a tiny scallop with a cauliflower mouse and caviar; I wanted more. The Foie Gras served with crushed berries and toasted brioche points was the best I've ever had; anywhere. Then came the lobster in a seafood broth and saffron oil drizzle. At this point I didn't know whether to smile or cry because the portion was just a bite. It was excellent! The main entree was veal wrapped in bacon but I asked for a different faire. Out came a beautiful Sea Bass with a pesto risotto that would make you want to slap your mama. I'm telling you the flavors were.....(fingers to mouth); I have no words. But I will definitely call ahead to order it soon. Lastly, dessert was a (and I hate to say this but..) soggy layered cookie atop a thin coffee flavored sauce. Did not like this one bit and not a good choice to close such a fabulous meal. I asked if we could get something else from the kitchen that would leave me satisfied. Our garon brought to us a wonderful warm molten cake with what tasted like date gelato; perfect with the port we were finishing. During the party/dinner Chef Philippe Gardelle would meet and greet his guests, take photos, share wine and just be the all around nice guy he appeared to be. At midnight we toasted the new year and was allowed to sit around until we felt like leaving. I think I've found my new favorite eatery only I hope the servings are larger when it is not a holiday.

Creme brulee. Sweet.We started our meal (our third anniversary dinner, mind you... thank you. thank you.) with a small appetizer of kabocha squash soup. It was magnificently tasty and my husband can not stand gourds, so for him to like this soup, well, it must be magnificent. Then we had yellow corn soup. This was very good but we would have preferred the squash soup in a serving this size instead of espresso size. For our main course I had a bowl of mussels (no, nothing else on the menu really appealed to me... but it was the early bird) and my husband had the pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon. Nope. Nothing really special here. Didn't make me feel special or like I was at d'Angleterre in Nice, France again. Now, for the shocking news. Love love love Clementine. When we received our bill there were business cards en le chapeau with Chapeau! on one side, Clementine on the other. OH NO. What's that about? Chapeau! bought Clementine. So sad. I will miss the old Clementine. Time to find a new French restaurant.

4.5 StarsI can't wait to come back here! The food and service were simply excellent. We were seated promptly and asked for our cocktail order. Our cocktails came quickly and we were allowed to enjoy them for a while until our menus arrived. I really appreciated that we weren't rushed! The waiter gave us good guidance in our food/wine selections. Normally waiters won't say what they really think, but my husband was thinking of ordering one thing, and he was like, " No, you should really order this." (in a nice way, and I agreed, but I didn't want to be a shrew and tell the hubby what to order, so I was grateful for this!)I had the sweetbreads - and they were excellent. They were creamy in the center, succulent and not overcooked (I had my fair share of overdone sweetbreads in Argentina). The boy had the salmon trio. I looked at other people's appetizers and it seemed like the two we chose were some of the best on the menu.  The only other thing that looked appealing to me was the warm brie. Maybe I'll try that next time.Oh yeah - and can I say the bread? The. BREAD. was. amazing! The most wonderful thing EVER. A perfect crust that shattered in my mouth and a wonderful, indescribable flavor. This is what real French bread must taste like. I never knew. I think I would choose this place over Gary Danko... Still great food, easier to get a reservation, less expensive, and less risk involved (because if you order the wrong thing, you can always come back!) For the entree I had the skate and the hubs had the flounder. Both were very good. I think with this restaurant it's more interesting to stay with the less traditional items on the menu. The filet mignon, cassoulet, foie gras, etc all looked very good, but not very ground breaking. The desserts were good as well. Again the waiter recommended the French toast over the creme brulee (cb is boring!). Do this. Do it, I tell you!The only reason I would downgrade this resto a bit is the decor. The tables are RIGHT next to each other and the decor is bland. It is very beige in there and it feels like it is missing something. Also the bathrooms was sloppily done - they chose a tile to match the existing tile, but it didn't match very well. Makes me wonder a bit what they do in the kitchen... But the food shines, so maybe they are just concentrating on that.
This is a pre-review for what WILL happen this Saturday night when we show up at 9:15 pm for our reservation. We'll wander in with red noses from the cold of walking the block or so from the 38 muni. When we get in, Philippe will embrace us and we'll feel like orphans who have finally been adopted by a family in the country with a farm and puppy and a tire swing. Then we'll be seated, most likely elbow to elbow, with the rest of the patrons. We'll probably make fun of the nicey-nice dressed people, some of the yuppie scum, but really, on this night our hearts will not be sullen but open to what the universe in the form of kitchen at Chapeau will give us. And we'll be totally starving, because I'll insist that we shouldn't eat for at least 8 hours before, to save room. Although maybe we'll cave and get a burrito somewhere at like 4 pm or something, but I digress...I'll order the cassoulet and this time, they won't be out of it. It will be like going back to my French roots and for a moment I'll become one of my ancestors from Pau, wandering home after herding goats, feasting on the hearty dish, warming his insides...and then for dessert I'll have something so delicious that I'll know it was a good idea to save my money and brown bag it every day this week. And then, our hearts and stomachs full, we'll leave, at first looking for Philippe but then heading out because we believe he's busy..but then he'll chase us down the narrow aisle between the tables and kiss us good-bye. Then we'll wander off into the night and go get wasted at some bar, but really, we'll be thinking about Chapeau.Yep, that's what's going to happen. An f-ing transcendental experience. [Philippe, if you're reading this, please make sure to have enough cassoulet to last until 9:15.]

Came here on a Wednesday night with a girlfriend. The restaurant was packed. We were a bit early for our reservation but were seated in minutes. The head chef and owner greets you when you walk in which is pretty nice. Once seated, we shared a nice french wine and our appetizers. We had the foie gras which was delicious and a pair of oysters. It was fun to try this stuff since my friend doesn't usually venture towards these options. For our entrees, she got the chicken, I got the Pork. Both were tasty but the dessert was by far, the best ending we could've asked for. GET THE FRENCH TOAST. You won't be disappointed. When we asked the waiter what to get, the chocolate cake (ordered by the table next to us earlier) or the french toast he said the french toast without any hesitation. And thank goodness, cuz after our first bites we both died and went to heaven. The toast they use is incredible and actually melts away in your mouth while the ice cream and sauce couldn't complement it any better. We had a great time. Just be prepared to spend a good two hours dining, it's a no rush, enjoy your meal like the French do type of bistro!

Chapeau is quite simply, amazing.You will approach a non-descript exterior and a paper sign will be all that lets you know you've got the right place. You'll pass through a nine foot tall, curved curtain wall of velvet, and you'll burst upon a scene that makes new comers go wide-eyed. I won't say more because it's more fun for you to find out on your own.The service is of a level I've seldom seen. Philippe (the owner) obviously loves what he does and you'll find him serving many roles: waiter, wine steward, busboy, maitre d', etc. He'll greet you and give you a personal goodbye when you leave. As mentioned, he'll chase after you if he some how misses you leaving. For us he was busy serving wine one minute, and then was suddenly outside the door when we walked out giving kisses and shaking hands. We each got Menu 2 and the amuse busch was a nice mushroom soup. I started with the foie gras, which I had paired with the sauternes. It was lightly seared, very smooth and rich. Microgreens, thinly sliced apples and a sweet sauce accompanied it. Next up was the tasting fish, which was a seared scallop with avocado, beats, and orange. It was cooked perfectly and tasty. For the entree I had the cassoulet and if you are a fan, you likely won't be disappointed. The duck was cripsy and the sausage had good flavor. All of the dishes were a nice size. No American, super sized portions here. Finally I had the profiteroles. Can you say "Yum"? I did.I did sample my guests onion soup, veal and creme brulee also. Each were excellent. I don't think you can go wrong with your selections and I didn't see an unemptied plate in the house.My guests and I shared a nice bottle of Bordeaux that Philippe brought out and expertly presented to us. Do have some wine, and fear not, this restaurant is relatively inexpensive for this level of quality.Make sure you have reservations. I can't imagine walking in and getting a table. Parking shouldn't be much of a problem.

At Chapeau! you'll have a dining experience like no other. It starts off with the confirmation phone call made by the owner Philippe's wife, whose excitement about your presence is truly sincere. When you arrive at the quaint little restaurant, don't be confused once you walk through the doors -- yes, you'll be shrouded in darkness by a heavy velvet curtain and wondering where to check in. But like being in a doctor's examining room and not knowing when you'll be seen by him, in a few minutes, the owner flings the curtain open with a huge smile and greets you with hugs and kisses. In his adorable French accent, he asks for your name and assures you that your table is almost ready. The restaurant is small, tables are inches apart, and above the elevated chatter of the patrons, you will hear the booming laughter of the animated owner who makes his rounds to each table, making sure everyone is enjoying themselves. He is truly a charming host, you feel like you're dining in his home.The pre-fixe menu is an incredible deal, and all of the choices look wonderful, making it hard to decide what to order. I decided to go with the 3-course $35 dinner, having the fried jumbo prawns to start, seared monkfish with risotto in lobster bisque as my main, and the warm chocolate cake for dessert. Fiancee went with the 4-course $42 dinner, having the same prawn appetizer, the tasting fish which was a scallop over an open squash ravioli, filet mignon with potatoes entree, and the trio of sorbets for dessert. The prawns were fantastic, my monkfish was incredibly rich because of the risotto in lobster bisque so I only managed to eat half of it, and the warm chocolate cake was heavenly. I really enjoyed the filet mignon, which was cooked perfectly and the flavors weren't too rich. Each course was a bit slow to come out, so our dinner lasted for 2.5 hours. As we left, Philippe was already outside chatting with friends, so when he saw us, he came over with open arms and gave us kisses and hugs goodbye, saying "See you next time!" It's always such a pleasure to meet people who genuinely enjoy what they do. It just makes for an enjoyable experience for everyone there.

If as a child I knew what I know now, I'd want to grow up to be Philippe Gardelle. He is truly a one man show. He's an amazing chef, gracious host, and top sommelier in the cityHe can find you the perfect bottle of wine for any menu combination. One night while dining for two, I asked for a recommendation for a half bottle of white before ordering a full bottle of red. He wasn't happy with what he had on his half bottle list to match our starters, so he opened a full bottle for us, poured half, and charged us half price. That's just the kind of person he is.The wine list is the best organized, most useful way of applying what I can only imagine is an anal personality. We had such a wonderful experience here.As soon as you sit down, you are made to feel liked you've been welcomed into the owner's home. Phillipe came out and greeted everyone in the restaurant with huge smiles and hand shakes. The food was excellent. I had the cassoulet and my husband had the lamb shank. My family ordered quail, ox tail, and the sauteed ling cod. We also also tried their 'fish taster' of the night, and that was an excellent seared scallop over risotto.The tables are close together, so you can't help seeing what other patrons were ordering. The special of the evening was prime rib, with four sauces, served table side. Phillipe and his wife, Ellen, served each special dish personally.For dessert, we had creme brulee, warm chocolate cake with rum raisin ice cream, a lemon tart, and the best (surprisingly) was the chilled orange soup. Sounds gross, but trust me, it is liquid heaven. Picture a beautiful orange liquid floating on top of a green base liquid in a martini glass. There were small slices of orange in there as well. I have never tasted anything like it. The orange was, of course, orange juice - but it was the sweetest juice you could ever imagine. The green turned out to be mint. Mixed together... Mmmm...As we left, Phillipe came out with us and gave us each a personal farewell. It was a fantastic evening. I've never felt so at home (meaning as if we had been invited to someone's house) at a restaurant.
Not much to add after the 330+ reviews already here. We LOVE this place. It's our new favorite, the place we went to for our recent anniversary. I should add we live in San Carlos & believe the 20+ mile trek to the Richmond is well worth it.We've been to Gary Danko a few times & think this is on par food-wise, though it doesn't quite match the service or ambiance (or price...GD is at least 2-3x more expensive).It's just wonderful. And there's something to be said for a place where the chef stops by your table & thanks you, tastes the wine you order with you, and sees you on the way out and shakes your hand or kisses your cheek.

I really don't like hearing somebody else's conversation when I'm having dinner. Unless I'm bored. I know many people prefer this place to Clementine, but I like Clementine more.
Best french restaurant I've ever been to. Food is enlightening, service is warm and wonderful, but most impressive of all was the pure hospitality of Chef Philippe. Our dinner guest suggested to Chef that the balsamic reduction was a tad burnt. Chef took the critique graciously and was sincerely grateful for the input. Chef followed his compliment with a bottle of fabulous gewurztraminer, gratis. So thoughtful and such a cordial demeanor. The remainder of the meal was unspeakably delicious. I especially noted the Salade Landaise, foie gras, the rabbit, and the french toast dessert. We plan on visiting again regularly in the future.

Maybe a little less than 3 stars but I'm kind of torn. Granted it's my own fault, I had pretty high expectations after looking at the reviews for this restaurant. Four of us came for my mom's birthday. Even though we were a little late due to traffic we were quickly seated with no problem. Yes, the chef made his rounds, shook hands at the table and upon our exit gave kisses on the cheek to the women, it wasn't warm. So after reading all the reviews, it just seemed gimmicky and disingenuous. Otherwise service was polite and receptive.On to the food. So. Salty. I was drinking water as if I had been laying out in the sun all day. My dad was thrilled to see they had a vegetarian option and happily decided on the vegetarian napolean.I went for the skate, my boyfriend the duck and my mom the halibut. My dad's food was o-k. My boyfriend's duck probably the best meal on the table. While my skate was o-k as well, the capers being a highlight. My mom's dish was pretty bad and it broke my heart because it was her birthday. We muddled through and found ourselves looking at the dessert menu. The chocolate cake while good was too rich at the end of this meal. The french toast however, AMAZING!!! My dad had the fruit napolean and my boyfriend the creme brulee, both run of the mill.All in all it was fine French food, but next time I want a French dinner I'll head over to le charm.

Wow. This French food rocks!Justin and I went to Chapeau! last Friday to celebrate his birthday a few weeks late. We both ordered off of menu 1 which allows you to pick one appetizer, one entree, and one dessert for $38. I had the baked brie appetizer (delicious), the sea bass (good, not great), and the vanilla creme brule (OMG!). J had the lamb shank and he was one content cookie. Served wtih couscous, the shank was HUGE. It was amazing. Justin also had an interesting dessert - orange sherbet soup. Definitely a creative option and pretty good, although my creme brule was better :)The service is definitely slow, but not unbearable in good company. Also, the tables are very very close to each other, maybe an inch or two of space between them. This was fun for us (we chatted with the couples on both sides of us throughout dinner) but I could see how it might not be for a couple hoping for a romantic evening.
If you come here with a dine-and-ditch in mind, you better rethink your plan. The chef/owner chases you down to bid you farewell, and if you decided to skip out on your bill, he looks like the kinda of guy who might be able to charm you into a headlock so he could pick your pocket before kissing you on both cheeks.My dad is crap at planning, so he put me in charge of picking a restaurant for my mother's birthday. I tirelessly yelped and yelped for days (ok, maybe just like 20 minutes) searching for the right spot. I ruled out any place too sceney, hipstery, trendy or with a Danko-esque price list. Chapeau!'s glowing reviews were the deal breaker. I called two weeks in advance and made a rather early reservation for five people.Now, I heard this place was small, but I wasn't prepared for the sea of heads I saw as I walked through the velvet curtains into the restaurant. They know how to pack the people in, that's for sure. I was a little bummed that our table was right in front of the door, so we caught every draft every time the door was opened, which was every two minutes being that the chef opens the door and welcomes everyone and opens the door to say goodbye to everyone. And if you thought I was bummed, you should have heard my mother."Brrrrrrr. Close the door! my feet are freezing! vrrrrrrr."Ya, mom's pretty much a huge complainer, and isn't shy with the bossiness. hey, she's a Jewish mommy from Oakland, what do you expect? A mousy, petite woman who crochets and drinks tea? Paaaaaa-lease! I get me potty mouth and road rage from that woman.The mealChampagne and wine were of course gorgeous, as champagne and wine tend to be1. cauliflower soup amuse-bouche....strong little treat that was perfect to dip my bread in2. warm brie over a potato pancake-type thing.....a didn't eat the whole thing because we were doing the "sharing" thing, but believe me, if it was my birthday I would have fought with fork prongs and elbows in order to horde that delicious bitch. ooooh, so yummy. I also enjoyed the goat cheese Napoleon.3. Bouillabaisse. I hate to be finicky, but from a restaurant that receives such high ratings, I was hoping for something more spectacular. The broth was really flavor-full and lovely. The clams and mussels were well cooked and flavorful, but the fish was way too fishy. Everyone who tasted it agreed with me. I really don't like fishy fish, which is why I never get salmon unless it's raw. My mother loved her fish (I think it was sea bass), my sister and brother-in-law got the cassoulet and sirloin. They both preferred the beef. Dad got the pork wrapped in bacon (heart attack on a plate. He probably had to take the whole bottle of Lipitor that night), and said it was good, but he didn't even taste the bacon.4. I think the desserts were the hit of the evening. We had the vanilla creme brulee, warm chocolate cake, praline cake and the apple tart. The creme brulee and chocolate cake were drool-worthy good. I'm not a sweets person, but at this particular meal I was the one at the end of the meal with my spoon scrapping the edges of the plates. Licking the plates would have been a little embarrassing for the fam, so I restrained myself.The servers were on top of the water, wine, bread, etc. But the service was really slow. Fortunately mom compared the meal to ones she had in France, which was a positive thing. She pointed out that since the food was so filling, it was a treat to be able to enjoy a long, leisurely meal where she wasn't stuffing her face.It was also on the Chevy's-level loud side. My dad kept screaming over me to talk to me mom. There was a lot of ear cupping and repeating. But the space is darling (the paint job is really cutsie and romantic), the service was delightful, the food was delicious, and the prices didn't force my dad to take a second mortgage out on the house. Not the most impressive meal ever, but I would definitely come back.

I wish that Yelp allowed half stars. If it did, Chapeau! would get 4 1/2 from me. Almost everything about my experience here was perfect, with the exception of one glaring oversight on the part of the server at the beginning of the evening. We were seated right away with a Sunday night dinner reservation at 8pm. The owner came by to introduce himself and personally welcome us, which was a nice touch. We were brought water and menus. And then we waited. And waited. And waited some more... We waited approximately 20 minutes for someone to bring bread, take a drink order, or take some sort of notice of our presence at all. Finally, our server came over, and abruptly asked if we were ready to order. There was no explanation of the menu, or the specials for the evening. I was particularly looking forward to trying the foie gras, which is not on the menu. Luckily, I had overheard him explain the foie gras to someone at a neighboring table, and asked about it. Still, no explanation of the menu or specials was forthcoming. He briefly explained the preparation to me (seared). He seemed completely rushed, and even somewhat bothered by being asked a question and having to take my order. Luckily, I had spent the prior 20 minutes studying the menu, so I knew exactly what I wanted to order by the time he finally deigned to acknowledge my existence. After the disastrous first 20 minutes, I was fully prepared for the rest of the evening to continue in the same fashion. Instead, I was delightfully surprised. Not only was the food delicious, the service for the rest of the evening was exceptional. Same server, but huge difference in service. I don't know what happened, but after the initial lapse, he did a complete 180 and was very attentive and courteous. He had:Deep Fried Black Tiger Prawns with Shredded Phylo Dough/Tomate & Onion Marmelade/Petits Legumes/Herbed Aioli - Very good. The prawns were perfectly cooked, and the flavor was nice and light. The phylo dough added nice texture, and the marmelade balanced out the flavors nicely.Bacon Wrapped Natural Pork Tenderloin/Parsnip Puree/Braised Green Swiss Chard/Apple-Calvados Sauce - You can't go wrong with anything wrapped in bacon, right?Tahitienne Vanilla Bean Crme Brle - Surprisingly large. Yum. I had:Seared Foie Gras - melt in your mouth deliciousness! I would go back here, repeatedly, just for this dish. Even the friend who dislikes foie gras and is repulsed by the general concept of fatty duck liver enjoyed this immensely.Roasted Rack of Lamb/Ratatouille/Potato Gratin -This plate is huge! It was too much food for me to finish, but I definitely enjoyed making the attempt. The lamb was moist and tender, very flavorful, a perfect medium rare. The potato gratin was very nice, as was the ratatouille. Warm Chocolate Cake/Banana Flambe/ Rum & Banana Ice Cream/Caramel Sauce - Rich, chocolately, divine. The warm, gooey chocolate center is my favorite part. Amuse Bouche (Smoked Trout/Potato Salad) - a tasty snackFish Tasting (Seared Scallop/Tomato Confit/Pesto Risotto/Fish & Lobster Reduction) - The scallop was so sweet and delicious, perfect with the fish and lobster reduction, it makes my mouth water just thinking about it.Palate Cleanser (Colonel: Lemon-Ginger Sorbet/ Citrus Infused Vodka) - The sorbet is light and refreshing, and the vodka gives an unexpected punch of flavorWe had a bottle of the wine recommended by our server, a merlot (actually a blend) that complemented the rest of the meal very nicely.I definitely plan to go back again. The food is an excellent value for the price, and I'm very impressed that they were able to change my impression of the place after the frustrating beginning to the evening.
Chapeau is remarkable in that it knows its aspiration and hits the mark. A small, warm space which, like the kitchen, is without pretension. The service has a component too often disguised as performance: service. Service not in the sense of subordination but a genuine caring that the guest is comfortable and well fed. We travel to SF from the south of the U.S. every two to three years, primarily to enjoy one of, if not the, great restaurant cities in the country. With such a vibrant dining scene, there is no shortage of new, cutting edge, and inventive restaurants so we love to keep current. But we also remember our friends. The folks at Chapeau are among them and we always return, usually our last night in town. Last evening was no exception. A cote de boeuf for two with marrow bone, a potato gratinee, string beans, and a satisfying brioche French toast with salted caramel ice cream and hazelnut englaise. Pascal made us feel we were guests in his home. Bravo!

Absolutely lovely.We arrived a tad early for dinner and I was a bit worried that we wouldn't be seated until our time, but Philippe greeted with kisses and we were immediately seated at our table for two. I assure you, you will not be able to find this Bistro easily. (unless you use google street views, have a GPS fitted in your rear or your navigator's been trained by the military). What at first seems to be your biggest faux pas ends up being your biggest accomplishment. Phillipe is a hyper-gracious gift to humans. I still cannot understand how he manages to run this adventure. I mean the guy plays chef, proprietor, and maitre d', opens every bottle at the table, tastes it along with his guests and then at the end of it all chases them down the streets to kiss them merci. My theory - the frenchman is on steroids. I mean there is no way a human can perform like this. We basically made our food selections and asked the staff for recommendations on the wine. Phillipe bought in a fruity 2005 Sablet and opened the bottle with his now made famous line "If you don't like it, I will drink it". The adventure started with a surprise - Melon Soup. Never had that before and I loved the tiny tangy flavor with it. Appetizers: The Tiger Prawns and the warm Brie spread up on potatoes. The Tiger prawns were allright but the Bried Potato was wonderful.Tasting Fish: Scallops were the choice. One bite into it and I was already scheming to plunder into my fellow diners' plate. Pallet cleansers: Both the colonel and the Trumond (?) had my guest and me hum "hmmmmm ......hmmmm ...hmmmmmm". Entrees: The monkfish and the filet mignon. I don't know how the beef gets aged but the medium rare creation was impeccable. The monkfish was stellar. Desserts: The "vanilla bean Creme Brulee" was stellar and the "Chocolate Cake with Creme Anglaise" was worth the 25 minutes. Lastly - while's its almost impossible, you probably might want to plan to take some food home. I have never seen a fancier of what essentially is a doggy bag. Overall Presentation Skills: 10/10Noise levels are certainly high but Chapeau! changes the way you look at things. This is the kind of food I want in heaven.

I had the skate wing which was by far the best skate I've ever had. Just perfect combination of spices, melting in my mouth and leaving a very refreshing aftertaste. The Filet Mignon was very flavorful and felt by itself like a 4 course dinner as the flavor changed as I let the flavor absorb. They also have an magnificent chocolate cake and Noue de Noix. Ambience is enjoyable and dimly lit. I also recommend you try their white Burgundy. Note on the side: Chapeau means "hat" in French; however, if it's chapeau! (with the exclamation mark) then it means "wow". And wow is the right description for this place.
May being the month of budding leaves, budding revolutions and budding love, we sought to celebrate my wife Jill's birthday amidst the parade of parties and protests. Having recently visited Paris, ah Paris!, we needed French cuisine. Our local expert for everything French, recommended that we try out Chapeau! in the Richmond district of San Francisco. As we munched potato-leek pancakes over mizuna, we delighted at the unexpected sweetness of caramelized apple. Each bite invited us to another bite and into a budding love of Chapeau! A bitter sorbet cleansed our palates--perhaps too bitter to want it to cleanse my plate again. The Cassoulet a la Toulousaine reminded me of the wonderful duck confit my friend Isabelle made for us when we visited her home in France. Mmmm. Warm, comforting country-style food. With a tad too much salt. For dessert, I took the predictably American path and went down the aisle of gushing chocolate cake. Who doesn't love chocolate cake? The rich sauce made me forget all my worries about the bitter sorbet and the tad too salty cassoulet. We made our reservations well ahead of time for the very early hour of 5:30 PM. As the room filled with customers excited about their night out on the town, the room also filled with noise. Sitting against the wall in the back of the room caused me to feel as if my head was floating amidst all of the chatter. I had to ask Jill to annunciate a little more clearly as I had a hard time hearing her. Near the end of the meal, she wanted to switch spots so that she could sit on the cushion instead of the wood chair. Doing so freed me from the cacophony but immersed Jill in it. Sitting elsewhere may have improved matters dramatically. As we finished the meal, the waiter remembered to call a cab for us without our even having to remind him. Before being whisked away to see Stevie Jay perform at the Yoga Loft, the bill came to us in a really cool hat. A chapeau, that is. The staff at Chapeau! treated us with special care. I'd like to think it was the festive hats we wore that night, but the staff at Chapeau! are probably always that good.

Undoubtedly the best value for money in any houte restaurant I've been to:I have been here twice with my friends and family, and both times I was not disappointed. The entrees I have tasted here (duck, scallops, pork, rabbit leg, steak) all were well presented and tastey. The appetizers were full of flavor, and I believe that some poor chef in the back had to have woken up at 4am that morning to pick the better produce for the ones I tasted.The owner takes great care to seat you, serve you wine, and see you out (a handshake for the men, a peck on the cheek for the women). All in all a fantastic find and great value for great flavor in this neighborhood.Only complaints I have are that it gets very busy: some of the less professional staff can become overwhelmed and forget about some of the little things if it's really busy. But aside from that small bit, a solid 5 stars.

As the name implies, Wow! Although I have heard over and over through the years what a treat this place is, I didn't quite believe it until experiencing it for myself. This is a little, unassuming gem in the Richmond. Not only does the owner and chef make a point of greeting you and saying goodbye individually, but the overall level of service is superb. For the food, we had the menu ($38 for a three course meal) and were served a complimentary amuse bouche of cauliflower coulis. We ordered a lovely Gewurtztraminer (Hugel) for our apps and then moved onto Le Galantin (Rouge) from Bandol. Menu-wise we started with:- Chevre napoleon- Warmed brie with potato dauphin and greens- Trio of salmon- Onion soupAnd onto the mains:- Lamb shank (looks like something Henry VIII would pick up and eat with his hands)- Seared seabass- Filet mignon- Perfectly cooked salmon- Tummy-warming cassoulet (dish of the southwest of France)And for dessert:- Vanilla creme brulee (perfect balance of vanilla, egg, and sugar crust)- Warm chocolate cake- Profiteroles (to rival the ones at Bofinger in Paris)Tarte grande mere (apple custard tarte). I am probably not going to point out anything that the other 300+ reviewers haven't already said. All I can say is do yourself a favor and go eat here!
didn't realize how small this place was, no wonder it was hard to get reservations. as soon as we walked in we were greeted. our table for two was in the back booth, very comfortable and somewhat private. we ordered the 4 course meal, i got the foi gras, filet minon, chocolate cake, and the fish of the day (included in 4 course meal). everything was prepared to perfection. the fois gras was one of the best i've had, it was served on top of bread dipped in olive oil and a side of sliced apples, very complementing. the fish was very good, very flavorful and moist. filet minon was juicy (medium rare). the food came out at the right time and were the right portions, my stomach was satisfied at the end and i was full but not overly stuffed.
I was greeted by Chef/Owner Philippe, which I quite liked, and I wished more chefs would introduce themselves at other restaurants (barely managed to greet my friend but that was quite alright). I arrived shortly after my 5 pm reservation, which was when the restaurant opened, and the place was almost full. Either everyone was trying to make it for the early bird (yes I went for the early bird) or they just ate that early.The Traditional Escargot de Bourgogne in Butter-Parsley & Garlic Sauce was very garlic (garlic taste still in my mouth after I gummed and brushed), butter, and salt intense. I accompanied it with the fresh, fluffy, soft, bland baguette to cut out some of the saltiness, which by the way I'm still trying to dilute out of my system.My entre, Prince Edward Island Mussels Steamed with White Wine, Shallot & Parsley, Pommes Frites & Rouille, was heavily peppered to zap the fishiness away. The broth gradually got more sour towards the end but that tends to happen from ramen to European dining. My friend described the fries as tiny versions of McDonalds, but I would disagree in that it tasted better, though some tasted bad, and probably greasier if that was possible. (Well I haven't exactly eaten McDonalds for the past two years, so forgive me if I'm wrong.) The dip tasted like fat in my mouth.Dessert tends to be my favorite part of any meal and it was my favorite of this night in relationship to the other two courses. The Tahitienne Vanilla Bean Crme Brule, Almond Tuile was creamy, rich, and HUGE. I love the caramelized top but I'm wondering if the custard portion was lacking in flavor because when I tried it without the lovely crystallized burnt sugar, I could still hardly taste the vanilla or custard flavor. When I ate it with the burnt sugar, I couldn't taste the crme at all. This wasn't my first time eating Crme Brule, but this was my first time noticing it. While I was serviced, I didn't feel rushed though there were people waiting. The waitress came by to tell us the unwritten menu items and refills of water kept coming. Chef Philippe checked on us once and gave the double cheek kiss as we exited. I saw a customer trying to read the menu with his pocket-sized blue LED light, which I thought was funny. There were two things that I felt uneasy about:1. The Chef was rarely inside the kitchen. 2. Though changing utensils after each course may be part of fine dining, I felt like I was wasting water because they all had to be washed whether used or not. We were in a state of drought just last year.

I love Phillipe. Half the time I don't even know what he is saying, but I smile enthusiastically and say "Yes! Sounds great!" For all I know, he is probably saying:"Tu as grossi!!" (You've put on weight!).....or..."Tu me peles le jonc" (You get on my nerves)Regardless, I just want him to keep talking. It sounds remarkably profound and, well, french! He is in the top 5 highest rated chefs in town. His food is incredible, as is his service. He greets his clients outside and always runs out of the kitchen to say goodbye to them. Once he chased us down the street for two blocks. (Perhaps it was because in a food coma frenzy we forgot to pay the bill...but regardless, I love the personalized attention!)My BF made him laugh...which resulted in complimentary dessert. We are skeptical people and proceeded to eye other tables to make sure THEY didn't get the complimentary dessert and that, in fact, WE were the truly special ones. Confirmed - we're the shizzle. Phillipe has two pre-fixe menus: 3 courses for $35 or 4 courses for $42. The food is no worse than Danko, at a third of the price. I had the foie gras, the bacon-wrapped veal with garlic mashed potatoes, and the apple tart. BF had the warm brie, the steak, and the chocolate delight. We had to be rolled out of there. In parting, Phillipe asked:"On t'a berc trop prs du mur?" I don't know what it means, but I nodded and gave him two kisses.
One of my favorite French restaurants in San Francisco.I want to bring all of my friends here one by one, two by two, whatever it takes until everyone I know can enjoy the precious dining experience of Chapeau!...The warm hospitality, the succulent and delicate flavors, the quaint and down to earth ambiance, the passion of the host/chef, the superb service--what else is there to say?I had the mesclun salad, salmon, and prailine cake. My partner had the scallop tasting fish, oysters, the monkfish, and the trio of sorbets. All were wonderful, not overpowering, heartwarming and delicious.Phillipe (host/chef) recommended a wonderful bottle of wine for us, and greeted us heartily upon our arrival and departure. What everyone writes about him is true--he's a real French gentleman.How else to compare this restaurant with others?Aqua is like the fabulous one night stand with a rock star---one who is unattainable, not one you'd not settle down with, but will always stand out in your mind.Chapeau! is the one you fell in love with, the one who became your best friend as well as lover--and best of all, being with them is the promise of a lifetime of one night stands.Go to Chapeau! to remember your French holidays, indulge yourselves, and remember not only what good French food is all about, but also how it should be enjoyed.

Wow, I am new to Yelp, but not new to this restaurant. I try not to add reviews to restaurants that have over 30 reviews, but I can't help it at Chapeau!. I will spare you my reviews on the food, you can read the 100+ others that talk about the menu. My first foray into this restaurant was in 2001, while I spent some time working in the SF bay area. On my company's expense account, I have hit up all the foody restaurants with the exception of Gary Danko. Everything else that was a Zagat 26+ on food in SF, Berkeley and Oakland, I basically tried at least once. Chapeau wasn't on an expense account, and it doesn't need to be. My friend suggested it, and at the time it was a Zagat 22 on food. (I'm not saying Zagat is the ultimate source by any means...it is now a 26). It was a remarkable experience. The food, wine list, service, Phillipe's hand shakes, kisses on the cheeks, everything about it was NOT what I had come to know for restaurants in the area. He and his wife make this place what it is...different, original, friendly, and a place you are welcome. Yeah it is cramped and sometimes hard to get a table, but not too hard. Since my first experience, I've been back there at least 15 times...with half of those times coming after I left the bay area. Every trip back requires a visit to Chapeau! Every friend that asks me what restaurant to go to, I say, "Well there is a place...my favorite place...it isn't in a fancy area...and don't be scared by the French guy..." and the praises go on and on.I love this restaurant and when I went back for my last visit in Nov 2006, I was more excited to see this place, taste the food, say hello to Phillipe and his wife...then to go to French Laundry. They make this restaurant that special.

When we arrive at Chapeau for dinner, the restaurant was almost completely full, and it was relatively early. We had a reservation, so i was a little disappointed with our extremely small table, and the close proximity of the tables to our left and right. It made the experience feel forced, rushed, and non-special. Unfortunately, this was a rough start to the night, but we told the hostess we'd like to wait for a more secluded table. Once we were sat somewhere more reasonable, I was able to concentrate on my amazing meal. This was the first time I'd ever tried Sweet Breads, and Foie Gras, and both were amazing, and the presentation was excellent. I could see why this place is so popular. It would be nice to feel less crammed for a return visit.

These guys need to bring the "French" back into their French Restaurant.After reading a ton of great reviews of this place I booked it for my fiance and I for valentines day.  $100 per person not including drinks so I thought we were in for a real trip back to France.  We were both exited to go as we had been to Clementine last year which we enjoyed tremendously, which is apparently owned by the same person as Chapeau.Anyhow, the hosts and service staff were very polite and attentive and did their job well. However, from what I could tell, all of the service staff were either Asian or Latino. That was the first bummer, we were all set to try out our french and there was no one to converse with. The meal was paced well and we were allowed to take our time and we really appreciated this. This was starting to feel a little more French.A real downer was the staffs lack of knowledge of french wines.  In my opinion French wines are like mysteries that need to be explained to truly appreciate each unique bottle. We were advised by a very well intentioned Asian gentleman to try a Grand Cru from the Bordeaux region. We were told it was very "smooth", which I kinda chuckled when I heard that. Anyhow, I asked what grapes comprised the wine and he was not able to tell me. When I pressed him on it he said Cabernet. Any of you wine buffs out there know that French wines are mostly blends, that is part of their craft and pride. He just didn't know what he was talking about and did not bother to find out for me.  I was thinking, IS THIS REALLY A FRENCH RESTAURANT? That bummed me out.Now to the food, I enjoyed the appetizers, the blini with caviar and salmon in pastry was very nice, they both featured the fish very well and did not overpower the intent. The oyster was good but I would have expected it in a restaurant know for Ceviche more than French food. On to the pancetta wrapped fish on risotto, this was good but not great. After the fish, they served us a filet mignon with truffle butter, asparagus and mashed parsnip. This pairing was excellent and in my opinion a perfectly balanced classic french entree, very nicely done.Dessert must have been uneventful as I cannot recall what we had.So this is my take, If your going to ask $350 for a French meal for two, I would expect that all of the elements come together perfectly. Knowledgeable French staff, excellent French wine with someone who knows and understands French wine, Slow French Pace to let us enjoy our meal and of course delicious French Food. I would have been down to say this meal should have fetched about $150 bones at best. So I am giving Chapeau 3 stars, wish it were better, but these guys need to bring the "French" back into their French Restaurant.

I've only been here once..not because it is expensive or lacks quality. In fact, Chapeau! is probably one of the best bang-for-buck French places I've ever been to. I've only been here once because it's so great it should be reserved for special occassions. Chapeau! is easy to miss given its small size and unassuming facade. As you enter through the door you are greeted by the chef and a roomful of patrons crowded into its not so large dinning area. Very crowded but very nice restaurant on Clement and 15th or so. Can't even tell its there until you go inside the big thick curtain at the front door. Service is very good and the food is EXCEPTIONAL. On top of that there is free parking on nearby streets and its right in my neighborhood in the Richmond district. Hard to find a restaurant like this in the middle of nowhere.Its right up there with the expensive french restaurants in downtown but minus the size, parking problems, and ambiance. It is cozy and comfortable.Prices are very reasonable for a restaurant of this class. You can expect about $40-60 per person without wine. I believe they even have a Pri Fixe (excuse my speeling) early bird 3 course for under $30 if you go sometime between 5pm and 6pm (better ask them to be sure).Philippe the owner is always warm and welcoming and always greets us when arriving. Sometimes he won't get to you when you are leaving because he is very busy but once we have been chased down the street to thank us for going. A very nice and charming owner that I am happy to give my business to.Casual clothing is totally OK at any of Philippe's restaurants (including Clementine on ~3rd and Clement). Their only rule is no cell phone use inside the restaurants.Reservations are recommended at least early on in the evening that you plan to go to be sure to get a seat.
The other night I went to Chapeau for a special celebration | occasion. Me and my friend walk into a totally crowded restaurant on a Friday evening, not one visible seat available and the chef comes up, smiles sincerely (not one of those horrible "pleasant bullshit" smiles...) and seats us in a comfortable table immediately. The waiter told us the specials, knew what wine to recommend with the food we ended up ordering for a reasonably price. I have to say this which is fantastic compared to the usual blow off (when no one knows didley about the wine the place is offering) of, "well... what you you likkkeee???"
