Delightful!I was treated to dinner here by my friend Denise L., and it was everything you would expect in a fine dining experience, minus the extravagant prices.The tables are very close together, and there is so much white linen that I felt like we were on board a luxury train in some forgotten era. The expertise of the wait staff also had this old-world feeling - they were nearly invisible in their service, but impeccable at anticipating and filling our needs. The place does not actually scream "French", which I liked (and honestly, from the name of the place I was scared that it might) - it just has an overall elegant yet very local feeling.The food was perfection in its preparation, presentation, and flavor. We started with the amuse-bouche of chilled melon soup, and a couple of glasses of yummy Cabernet champagne.We both decided on the $35 menu: which included an appetizer, main course, and dessert.Course 1:Me: Heirloom Tomato Salad - big, ripe slices of heirloom tomatoes in an olive oil and orange vinaigrette with toasted pine nuts. Fresh and bursting with flavor - with just a hint of orange for complexity. Delicious.Denise: Mixed Green Salad - exceptionally fresh greens in a vinaigrette with Laura Chenel goat cheese both in bites in the salad and in the dressing. Lovely.Course 2:Me: Veal Wrapped in Bacon - beautiful dish - large fillet of veal prepared med-rare, with bacon wrapped around it and topped with a sauteed sweetbread, all atop a portion of creamy garlic mashed potatoes. The whole thing was surrounded by a wine/brown sauce with mushrooms and cipollini onions - the smell of it as it was set down on the table was so powerful that the diner next to me (and by next to me, I mean practically sitting on my lap!) asked me what the dish was. It went beautifully with the earthy glass of Bordeaux that I savored.Denise: Petit Poussin - tender pieces of poussin served atop julienned vegetables - truthfully, I was so into my dish, I barely remember this one except that I thought it was very good.Course 3:Me: Apple Tarte Grand-Mere - again, perfect. Ultra thin layers of apple atop a custard filling, all in a shortbread crust. Served with a dollop of hazelnut ice cream.Denise: Warm Chocolate Cake - oooooozing dark chocolate, and great quality chocolate at that. Served with a dollop of vanilla ice creamThe chef Philippe Gardelle greeted us at the table soon after we arrived, and then again as we were leaving. It's nice to feel that you are truly appreciated, and I know we had genuine smiles on our faces after our wonderful dinner.Great place for a date, dinner with the parents, catching up with a friend, or an upscale celebration. The intimate nature of the restaurant makes it challenging for children. Portions are ample but not overpowering, which we appreciated. Definitely a great value considering the high level of service, quality, and overall experience. This is a smooth operation, and they are experts in the dining experience. The loyal clientele that had the place constantly full on a Tuesday night is an testament to Chapeau!'s word-of-mouth reputation as a great find in a less obvious neighborhood.I can't wait until my next visit - merci, Denise! Merci, Chapeau!!
OK so we ate here for valentines day and it was a set six course French meal. Both of us had never eaten French food before and we were very happy. First off its a small place with a full bar and nice wine selection. The tables are pretty close together but the service is excellent. Our first course was a tuna tartare. It was really really good. Second course was a beet (yea beet) carppachio with candied walnuts and goat cheese and it was bomb. Third course was roasted quail served over a mizune salad, the quail had nice crispy skin and tender flavorful meat and the salad was light and citrusy. Fourth course was monkfish over a lobter Risotto with a parmesan tweel, I liked the flavors of the fish and Risotto but she didn't care for it much. Fifth course was a beef medallion over scallopped potatoes with a red wine reduction sauce and also on the plate was a big bone with a spoon in it to eat the marrow. This plate was the best so far. About midway through our meal before we were served this course the chef himself came to our table and asked us how we'd like our beef cooked I told him to make it the way he likes it so I got rare and she got Med tame then he even convinced us to get two glasses of wine. The meat was delicious. And the bone marrow was interesting but tasty. Its a bit texterally unpleasant but if that's not a probably for you then you'd. Like it. Last for dessert we received a pear panna cotta with. A cookie. It was the perfect light cold dessert to end the meal. We look forward to coming back and trying the reg menu which is why I'm only giving it 4 stars. Its a little pricey but def a nice place to eat French food for a nice romantic dinner.

I've lived close to this neighborhood for 17 years and never noticed this place.The staff was very attentive right from the moment you pass through the entrance adorned with a heavy black curtain which makes the place feel more exclusive. Warning: As this is a review for a French restuarant, I'm going to be just a tiny bit saccharine and liberally litter my high school French phrases alllll over. This place has a charm I cannot resist. Despite it's setbacks, I like it here.Sure, the decor is French Marshalls discount store: frilly wall murals, bright lighting.  So what! Sure, the tables are one on top of another. But hey, that means good eavesdropping AND the fun of shocking your neighbor with inappropriate conversation.  Sure, the space is small, with no waiting area. So don't arrive early for your reservation: that way you won't have to wait next to the bathrooms like we did.Food is comforting, predictable-ish Frenchy.  Basically the same menu I remembered from eating here a year ago. But that can be a good thing. Even I can get tired or aggressively seasonal, ever-constant menu changes. Because sometimes I want the same old thing.Same old thing as of last night was cassoulet. I remember it being ideal - and because I'm planning on making my own this coming weekend, I needed to be inspired.To my disappointment, the cassoulet was not the textbook image of perfection I envisioned. It was a bit soupy - the beans had not given off that creamy starchiness that binds everything together. Lamb advertised was undetectable. Tomato flavors were too pronounced. And no crusty top layer, with breadcrumbs sprinkled as a seeming afterthought.But I sense this was a one-off fall from grace. Because everything else was delicious: simple salad with sweet-ish dijon-y dressing, amazing melted brie on potato pancake with nicely dressed bitter greens and walnuts; richly savory filet mignon even despite my friend's request to cook it (gasp) medium-well. Molten chocolate cake was a perfect rendition of this often-bastardized dessert.And how could you not love the owner? He is charming. He kisses you on both cheeks. He has chosen an excellent wine list brimming with reasonable, interesting bottles. He cares.  And it shows.

4 1/2 STARS!! I am SO glad that I finally got to try this place! The food and service is absolutely amazing!!! I loved everything about it! (I'll explain the missing 1/2 later.) I had the pleasure to enjoy this fabulous meal with Liz S. last night. We both had the $35 3 course meal. I was impressed by the prices, but I have to admit it worried me a bit about the food. I started with the mesclun salad with mixed greens, beets, candies walnuts and goat cheese. It was delicious! The dressing was perfect and the cheese was not too overpowering. All the ingredients were de-constructed on the side of the plate and the mixed greens and cheese were in the middle. Great presentation!For my entree I had the petit poussin. Step into the tiny space of Chapeau! and transport yourself to the French countryside. Although this is a small restaurant, the warm butter-yellow walls (stenciled with climbing vines which creep onto the ceiling), crisp white linens, and spot lighting create a cozy and romantic setting.The menu sets (choice of three or four courses) are probably the best bargains. Their asparagus soup is light, creamy, and refreshing. The foie gras (a specialty appetizer for the evening) included two generous pieces of fatty, sizzling pieces, arranged artfully alongside a small heaping of mixed greens, sliver-thin slices of tart apple, and a buttery disc of brioche. The duck was tender, perfectly cooked, and drizzled with a meaty demi-glace. The desserts (a medley of mango, kiwi, pineapple, and strawberry, and the warm chocolate cake) were heavenly. Service was courteous, and each course was served at precisely the right time and at a perfect temperature. Discreet servers kept our wine and water glasses filled without us ever asking. You will want for not at Chapeau! A true gem in the Richmond.
Simply the best French restaurant I've ever had the pleasure of visiting. Phillipe (owner and master chef) is incredibly involved with every part of the restaurant. He greets you when you arrive and will talk at great length about the dishes he has prepared and the ones he is planning for the future when you leave after your incredible meal.The food is presented artistically and the flavor matches the visual aesthetic. The waiters are attentive and polite. But what really stands out is the quality of the ingredients and attention to detail. There are layers upon layers of subtle culinary brilliance in each dish.All in all, this is an experience that will leave you completely satisfied. I would recommend Chapeau! for any occasion where you have something to celebrate, because the food is itself a celebration of life.I cannot wait to return.

Chapeau! beautifully accommodated a 6-person birthday dinner last night, from the double-kiss greeting at the front door, to the champagne and palette cleanser to the appetizers (I loved the mesculin salad with fried Brie, a friend enjoyed her salmon terrine with grilled capers, and two had the onion soup--no need to call it "french" onion soup here!), the wine was perfect, and the entrees were amazing. A couple of our party shared the 2-person prime rib special that came with four sauces--the Roquefort was incredible), the salmon and halibut were also awesome. The fennel with the halibut was a perfect compliment. Others had the lamb and the fillet, and all plates were returned completely bare. We all had the choose your own three-item prix-fixe menu ($33), so dessert was included. I think they brought us every single one b/c we had a birthday girl, so I tried the vanilla creme brule (dreamy) and the warm chocolate cake (liquid heaven), and others had the classic french profiteroles that also looked crazy-good. Note to vegetarians--no need to avoid this place b/c it's french (notorius for serving meat in every course and in every sauce), they have a whole vegetarian portion of the menu! The great service extended beyond the personal attention from the proprietor. We had about four wait staff making sure that wine glasses were full and that we were served at the same time--no easy feat for a six-top in in a small restaurant. The atmosphere was quiet enough to hear each other talk, but wasn't stuffy. Parking wasn't even that bad. I can't wait to go back--one of the best values in town for some of the best food I've had in a long time.Apparently Chapeau! with an exclamation point means "wow" instead of hat--I was definitely wowed!

Well...fabulous, just fabulous! Just the previous evening we were at Clementine, another neighborhood French restaurant of comparable size, one mile East on Clement, and comparisons are inevitable.Where Clementine is good, Chapeau! is excellent from food to service. Latter is assured & confident. The food is on a par with the City's good n'great. Fois Gras could have been served at Fleur de Lys, the Balsamic reduction with the generous Heirloom Tomatoes perfect - one of the few chefs that knows when to hold back.Bouillabaisse & Cassoulet are widely open to interpretation, and we liked this kitchen's rendition of each a great deal. Neither dish was over-sized but each portion was spot on with first rate ingredients.Wine list had many bargains and credit to the chef owner for taking a couple of pages to highlight quality wines around the $30 price point. We asked for advice from our waiter regarding a white burgundy and he immediately referred us to the proprietor who gave very reasonable, knowledge based, advice.Now what really sets this establishment apart is a service issue worth sharing. The menu has a couple of prix-fixe options and we had originally gone a la carte with our thinking to not indulge in a dessert. Having decided (thankfully, in retrospect) to ultimately relent and share a profiterole we found out it was subsequently comped. Classy.It is a cramped space, and our enjoyment was no doubt enhanced by having a two-top set somewhat apart from the millieu in the window, but everybody seemed to be having a great time. Got the sense this was more of a Richmond district neighborhood joint (Clement & Fifteenth Ave), but this pair of very much East of Twin Peaks gadabouts came away thinking this was the best meal we've had inside City & County boundaries for a very long time.Very much recommended.

Chapeau! is a wee, unassuming restaurant (with one of the most unexpected, ghettoest signs I've seen) that is tucked into the mid-Outer Richmond. My friend ordered the Poached Wild Alaskan Halibut, which was pretty good, but it was my Hickory Smoked & Pan Seared Alaskan Salmon that stole the show. True-to-form, every smoky bite melted in my mouth. For dessert, we had the Warm Chocolate Cake with Creme Anglaise, which was a lot lighter than the lava cake-like concoction that I had envisioned it to be, thankfully.My only quibble is that in for a restaurant where the service is lauded, Chapeau! came up short. I was given water with ice after I had requested it without. Also, the waiters made a few misjudgments in terms of when we needed to be attended to and when we didn't. Lastly, the chef never came out of the restaurant to wish us farewell as he was reputed to. Harumph.I'd still recommend Chapeau! in a heartbeat, however.

Note (March 20/07): I just noticed that my accenting of French characters vanished! So I've gone and fixed things, but with the unaccented, plain vanilla English letters. Everything else is the same. *sigh* [end note]Well, I suppose it had to happen one of these days...a 5-star review. Which can only mean one thing...I had an absolutely amazing meal and experience! My father, who has "dined all over the world, including in many Michelin star restaurants" declared this place to be so amazing that he wrote on the comment card "tous les saveurs sont magnifiques! Merci bien pour une experience extraordinaire!" (if you'll forgive my butchering of French grammar). Despite my dad's tendency for exaggeration and superfluous superlatives, this was truly a meal to remember. The chef and owner, M. Phillipe Gardelle, quite obviously enjoys his craft and his attention to detail and inventiveness clearly shows through in every plate that leaves the kitchen. And every time he runs out the door to bid adieu to his guests. He told us he decided to come to San Francisco from France for 2 years - 15 years ago! France's loss, our gain.M. Gardelle has created a fantastic restaurant tucked away in what's almost the middle of nowhere, nestled amongst synagogues, Chinese markets and restaurants, and a lot of houses. The bistro is small and cramped, but not unpleasantly so. We were lucky to get in because somebody canceled their reservation. On to the meal! After going ga-ga over the menu, we were informed of the specials that evening - rib steak for two, served with gratin and marrow bones. And if that wasn't enough for the third person at the table (who will remain nameless to protect her aura of innocence), they also had foie gras. So that settled it for her, and decided that marrow bones required ordering that large steak, so she and my dad had that. He had the moules avec pommes frites (the best damn frites I've ever had, possibly a tie), and I had the warm brie over a potato pancake served with some frisee of sorts. All were absolutely amazing. And so was the half glass of Sauternes wine that went with the foie gras. Wow.Then we had decided to go for the 4 course menu because the "fish tasting" course consisted of a pan seared sea scallop (yum!) served on top of an "open ravioli" with butternut squash filling and a citrus honey sauce. Now I'm not the biggest butternut squash fan in the room, but this was phenomenal. The scallop was cooked to perfection (as my dad remarked many a time throughout the rest of the night), and the combination of flavours was completely unexpected and awesome. (I'm going to run out of superlatives soon...)The mains arrived, and the steak was sliced and served at the table for the other two diners. Complete with rib bone and two giant marrow bones. Even with meat served at the table, they went out of their way to present it impeccably, and I had a taste of the wonderful meat that was garnished with a bit of fleur de sel and served with four amazing sauces - roquefort, bearnaise, peppercorn, and truffle. I tasted all four, and the roquefort and truffle were the very clear winners to the point of making me want to grab the little dish and just drink the stuff down.Having just had a steak the previous night (see my review of Sundance...it's nice when parents visit!), I had opted for the cassoulet, which is apparently a French peasant-ish kind of dish. Either way, it consisted of white beans (which normally I'm not a big fan of, but decided to go for it anyways), braised lamb, a duck leg, and a small sausage. The duck meat fell apart in my mouth and the lamb was already largely mixed in with the sauce. The sausage was incredible.And then as if this kind of gluttony wasn't enough, we couldn't forget the dessert portion of the 4 course menu. Most of them looked and sounded amazing. We collectively had the chocolate cake (totally worth the 10 minutes for them to make it from scratch), the profiteroles, and and orange concoction that contained orange sorbet, creme de menthe, and Grand Marnier. All were excellent. And we also got a serving of a fourth dessert, the diced fruits in basil cream and with thin cookies. Heavenly, all of it.The wine was also excellent - a Hautes Cotes de Nuits that nicely complemented all of our meals. And taking a look through the wine list, I was completely impressed with the selection, the prices, and also just how easy it was to find the kind of wine you were looking for.All in all, Chapeau! lives up to its name, both for bringing the bill in a chapeau, and for making you go wow! many times during the meal.Sante!

The beauty of this restaurant in the Outer Richmond is that it is relatively inconspicuous. Without searching it out ahead of time, you would never know what delights lie within.  Oh...and the delights are worth the trouble of trying to locate this little Bistro on Clement Street.When we walked in, we were a bit disconcerted by the deep velvet black curtain guarding the entrance way. We had not made reservations, but we were seated immediately. The place was crowded and the noise level was a bit high, but the other aspects of the ambiance were rather pleasant.The walls are a warm yellow, very Provencale and very inviting. This is a white table cloth establishment, but also charmingly allows for dressing comfortably (not messily of course!). The beautiful pink rose that sat between me and my dining partner definitely set the romantic mood. We started out with Champagne by the glass (Ruelle-Pertois Premier Cru Blanc de Blancs, a very small winery, which I had never hear of that produces about 40,000 bottles or so annually). My main course was the Prince Edward Mussels in white wine sauce and pommes frites. My dining companion chose the Salmon with leeks, potatoes and red wine butter. The mussels were delectable, but admittedly weren't as good as the mussels that I had enjoyed at a little seaside restaurant last year *sigh*, but, I devoured every single one of them. My boyfriend's plate was CLEAN. In fact, he used the wonderful, crusty French baguette to wipe every last trace of sauce from his plate. For dessert, I enjoyed the profiteroles (very petite and hit the spot) and my boyfriend savored the warm chocolate cake.  Overall, the food was solid. Yet, the warm service from the owner was what makes the place memorable. I think that this little Bistro deserves a second try in the future.

Mmmm...WOW... That is the reaction my boyfriend and I had to every morsel we happily devoured at this restaurant. If I could give six stars I would. What a dining experience.Our server recommended a white burgundy, which was fabulous and went really well with our food. A server brought out an amuse bouche to start, a demitasse of a cream of mushroom soup. Excellent. A very promising start to what was to be an exquisite meal.For appetizers we shared the mesclun salad, which was deliciously dressed greens, pistachios, grapes and a piece of goat cheese that was fried with a lightly battered and crispy outside and smooth, melting creaminess on the inside. Each bite of salad was flavor heaven. We also shared the french onion soup gratinee. Unbelievable. One of the best onion soups I've ever had. We also decided to try the seared foie gras. Not PC but I have been wanting to try this culinary delight for a long time. And delightful it was. It was seared on the outside and very soft and smooth on the inside. Extremely rich, served with a piece of toast soaked in a sweet sauce, a side of microgreens and thinly sliced apples. Sooo good!For entrees I ordered the halibut, which was served with a saffron and celery root broth with fennel, fettucine and a piece of crispy toast with smoked salmon paste. My boyfriend ordered the sauteed monkfish, which was served with risotto in a lobster bisque. Both dishes were nothing short of sublime. We have not had fish that perfectly cooked in a long long time, so moist and delicate. Just amazing.For dessert we ordered the apple tart with hazelnut ice cream and a dollop of caramel, and the vanilla bean creme brulee. The creme brulee was perfection, and the tart was excellent, especially with the ice cream, which was bursting with hazelnut flavor and so damn good. The service was superb, attentive without being overbearing. The restaurant is very cozy with some tables that are very close together. We asked to be moved to a table by the window, which the server obliged, and we enjoyed our meal happily and comfortably. The owner/executive chef, Philippe Gardelle, greets everyone when they arrive, and graciously thanks and says goodbye to everyone as they leave with a handshake for the men and a European double kiss for women. What top notch restaurant can you think of that provides that kind of genuine gratitude and service? Chef Gardelle's desire to serve the customer is also evident in the fact that our bill, which charmingly arrived in an actual chapeau, also comes with a comment card. Chapeau serves food and provides service that is as good as it gets. Completely unpretentious with food that speaks for itself. A genuine, classic French culinary treasure in the Richmond District.

my new mission in life is to get fat via french food.if a little neighborhood bistro like this has the same big french food chops as the best this city has to offer, AND retains the warmth and friendly ambiance of a real french bistro, i have really just died and gone to le ciel francais. i've only had one great bistro meal prior to chapeau, and that was in paris with my francophile friend from grad school.$25.50 for the early bird three-course prix fixe menu; they didn't rush us as we leisurely sat and conversed at the table sipping our white bordeaux. i had the salmon 2 ways appetizer. chopped raw salmon marinated with good oil, salt and dill, wrapped in fresh raw salmon fillets with minced hard-boiled eggs, creme fraiche and fried capers decorating the exterior rim of the plate. simple, salted goodness with just the right proportions of egg and capers to the salmon.my main was a moules mariniere with frites and spicy mayonnaise accompaniment. the moules were local and fresh, infused with a savory white wine sauce that took every ounce of strength for me not to pick up the bowl and pour it down my throat after i had finished with the mussels.dessert. i hate eating and ordering dessert, but this was simply the best part of the meal. i had the red wine soup, which turned out to be a savory red wine reduction with vanilla bean ice cream (yeah, i know, i'm totally paying for it tomorrow morning) and creme fraiche sitting atop a sesame biscuit and surrounded by fresh berries. service was on cue, and the staff were patient and sweet. i want to go there again. tomorrow. right at 5pm. god help me.
This is a review from Sam an eight year-old:Good service . Great food. I had the cassoulet which is beans and duck and sausage cooked in a pottery bowl. It was excellent. I also had frites which are french fries. For dessert I had the profiteroles which are iceceam in pastry with chocalate sauce on top. Super yummy.
this restaurant is so good i dont know who would mind philippe's bisous as he shows you out. the food is not your typical bistro food, but really quite few steps up with regard to presentation and ingredients. you wouldnt think so from the dinky facade so they may be redoing the front or just trying to keep the place another one of san francisco secret bijoux in the city. anyway, the amuse bouche was a cold soup of melon and mint. a little different , and although i dont have a taste for mint in my soups, it was refreshing.i had the seared foie gras with PERFECT and brioche (dont you hate it when the brioche is too thick? it's the mark of a careless restaurant, i think) with only a hint of butter and went nicely with the paper thin slices of apple. fantastic. i moved on to the scallop for our fish course and though it really is only one scallop, it was quite enormous and seared just so that the top is slightly charred but the inside is still soft, chewy, and mmm it was so tasty. it was dressed with avocado cream, micro diced beets and a sliver of orange (or was it tangerine?). mmm. so tasty.the plat was an enormous cote de beouf (shared between two people), which i think was a special for the day, but they were wonderful enough to accomodate our different tastes; mine was seared and the other half was medium rare. the beouf came with not only the marrow still tucked into the bone but four sauces: bearnaise, peppercorn, black truffle, hollandaise. i liked the black truffle best, but the meat was seasoned so well i didnt end up using any of the sauce at all.for the dessert, the basil napoleon has MANILA MANGOES. i just want to say that i havent found any manila mangoes anywhere in california and they are the best mangoes in the entire world. they had micro bits of fruit drizzled with confectionary sugar and it was a nice, light end to the meal.this might've gotten every long but we had a wonderful experience at chapeau (i touched up in the bathroom and came back to find my napkin neatly folded back on the table) and it really is not as expensive (and definitely not as stuffy) as some of the nice french restaurants in sf AND they have some early bird specials with great dishes at ridiculous prices you wont even believe. the only trouble here is that the tables are quite close together, but thats really all i can nitpick about. definitely coming back, maybe a once a month ritual.
It was six o'clock on a Wednesday evening. I was in the city and was really in no mood to drive home to Berkeley in the traffic. While Disneyland is the happiest place on earth, the Bay Bridge at six o'clock is the exact opposite: the saddest place on earth. Having decided to stay in the city for dinner, the boyfriend and I drove to another French restaurant in the Richmond just to find it closed. Am I GLAD that it was closed for renovation! If not, I would have missed the opportunity to dine at the amazing Chapeau! First of all, the service is excellent. The staff is friendly and patient. I was being extremely indecisive partially because I was very tired, but the maitre d', who also helped us in the beginning of dinner, did not get annoyed with me once. (Or was she the wife of the owner that other yelpers have noted?)Just as those who have come before me and those that will follow, I'm going to rave about the $38 three-course meal and the $45 four-course meal. The only problem I had: what am I going to settle on with the great selections offered? I wanted at least 4 of the appetizers: the foie gras, the scallop in lobster bisque, the French onion soup, the frisee salad; I wanted them all! So I went with the pan seared foie gras on a brioche paired with a half-glass of Sauternes, filet mignon, and creme brulee while he went for the duck confit salad, sea bass, and warm chocolate cake. I didn't know what hit me when I finished the foie gras. Where did it all go? I finished already? I needed some more immediately if not sooner! The Sauternes was perfect with it. The filet mignon was tender and flavorful with a fantastic layer of mushroom and surrounded by perfect little bite size pieces of potato. The creme brulee was classic vanilla bean creme brulee at its best. The ductk confit salad, which was topped with a small piece of seared foie gras, was nearly as amazing as the foie gras on brioche. The sea bass, however, I found a tad "fishy." Finally, the warm chocolate cake, it was absolutely incredible! Accompanied by a scoop of ice cream with raisins and a drizzle of caramel with rum, I had to keep inching across the table to steal bites! As we exited the restaurant, the maitre d' swept the velvet curtain back, thanked us with sincere appreciation, and wished us a good night. I think I'm still in heaven right now, somebody please come and pull me back down to earth.

Chef/owner Phillipe and his lovely spouse Ellen really made this a very special dinner with their personal touch throughout the meal. everything from the grilled scallop in a cream tomato risotto to the perfectly grilled salmon to the cheese platter and the exquisite chilled orange soup was fantastic! Phillipe came from La Folie and his heritage definitely shows here in his own venue. Wine selection is also very impressive. Two thumbs up with a French style kiss on both cheeks!

Again, we were treated to gastronomic experience with sauted Sonoma foie gras with a peach reduction that left me wanting more, sweet breads bathed in wild mushrooms and its sauce -- probably the best I've ever had, and crispy duck confit on cabbage with Applewood smoked bacon that was almost not shared... just for starters. My main entree was tender lamb on the bone, fit for a queen. Always a pleasure.Worth noting: Philippe Gardelle has put together a wonderful wine list that includes a fine list of wines for around $30. When we inquired about a certain unlisted varietal, he mentioned that the recent vintage was poor and he really didn't like anything. He has to like the wine before it's presented to his customer. Thank you!

Solid 3.5 stars. I have been wanting to come here for a while now since my BFF tells me it's AMAZING. So I had really high expectations. To celebrate my birthday, some friends took me here. The restaurant is small but cozy, and looks like a nice neighborhood place. We had 8pm reservations and were seated promptly. The place was packed with people waiting at the bar. For dinner, I opted for the prix-fixe menu, where you could select an appetizer, entree, and dessert for a pretty decent price. For appetizer, I ordered the deep fried tiger prawns. It was good and the batter was light and crispy. My friend got the onion soup, which I tried and also thought was tasty. The cheese was nicely melted and gooey. For my entree, I got the special that night, which was the pan seared scallops over risotto. This was good. I enjoyed it. Hubby got the duck and that was pretty good too. My friend got the filet mignon and asked for it medium rare but unfortunately, it came out almost well done, so it was tough and chewy, without a lot of flavor. Her husband got the pork tenderloin and it was a bit on the bland side, as well. When the server came over to ask how our entrees were, my friend told him the filet was overcooked. The server was very nice about it and apologized and offered to take it back, but since they already ate half of it, they didn't want to make a big fuss. To make it up to us, they gave us 2 desserts on the house, in addition to the ones we already ordered. That put our total to 7 desserts. LOL. It was definitely dessert overload. I really enjoyed the napoleon, surprisingly. I didn't think I would like it but I really enjoyed how fresh it was with the all the fruits. It definitely wasn't like a traditional napoleon. My other favorite was the profiteroles. The french toast was interesting since I would typically associate that with breakfast rather than dessert. It was a bit sweet for me because of the caramel they drizzled on top, but my hubby really liked it. Overall, the experience at Chapeau was good but not great. I guess I just had really high expectations, given the raves and reviews. I would come back again to give it another try.

i love this place! i saw it on an episode of check please bay area on KQED a while ago and had wanted to go ever since. Ray and i were in the city last weekend and it was the perfect time to go. we made reservations a few weeks in advance through open table, and even then we could only choose 6:00 or 8:30, so we knew it was going to be busy. we opted for the 6:00 reservation, and when we arrived last saturday night, we knew which table was ours, it was the only one open!it was a lone table in the front window, which was nice because we didnt have to deal with rubbing elbows with the people at the tables next to ours as other people have noted. it was loud, but since i was expecting it after reading reviews here, it didnt bother me. we of course went with the prix fixe menu. ray ordered the french onion soup, but they were out so he got the creamy vegetable-type soup (i cant remember the name. oh yes, veloute!) and it was so good! he ordered the bacon wrapped pork and the chocolate cake for dessert. he liked it all! i cant say anything about his, i liked mine too much to even think about what he was eating!i had the warm brie on the potato and leek dauphine (it was good, not awesome really, except the purple sauce that was on it, it was VERY good!). for my entree i had the filet mignon and this is the real reason i am giving this place 5 stars. i have NEVER had a steak cooked as perfectly as this one. and it was perfectly seasoned, served with garlic-type mushrooms and something sort of like home-fries, little perfect cubes of perfectly fried potato. oh my god. seriously, i think it may have been the best entree of my 24 years of existence. for dessert, i have the tarte grand mere and again, oh my god! the crust was perfect, the custard was not too thin and not too thick, and the apples were tender but still had their texture, and were not too sweet. i really liked that the scoop of vanilla ice cream served next to the tarte was sprinkled with a little turbinado sugar, it added a good texture. ray said that his rum rasin ice cream had the same sugar, something so simple made a big difference!we didnt have anything to drink except water, and we had to be the only people there not drinking wine, just not our thing. but their wine list was very extensive and there seemed to be something for everyone there.so it was a little over $100 with tip, and it was worth every penny! the only thing was that parking was really hard to find, so we had to walk abotu 5 blocks, but it could have been worse. the atmosphere was very laid back and casual, not stuffy at all. i would definitely come back here!

This weekend was my brother's 30th birthday. However, I had promised M that I would attend a wedding down in LA. I get an email from my brother's fiancee indicating that there was a birthday party Sunday which I thought was going to work out well. We even decided to go to the airport to try to catch an earlier flight. Due to less than stellar flight conditions at SFO, we were delayed getting in which we then promptly rushed to San Francisco. We walked into the restaurant at 10:10pm at which point we were informed the kitchen was no longer taking any orders after 10pm. This is my first review on this site, and I am more than happy to be writing about this restaurant. All in all, I had a really great experience here when I came to dine with my father's best friend from out of town.Though the neighborhood was so-so, it was very nice to find a gem like this in such an inconspicuous location. Once we beat our way through the heavy black curtain at the door, we didn't quite realize that we had smashed our way into a den of gastronomical excellence.The truly beautiful thing about this place is its simplicity. The decor is elegant, not pretentious. The servers were polite, knowledgeable, and generally quite receptive to the nonverbal "vibes" we went them -- they seemed to just KNOW when my water needed to be refilled, when my wine glass needed replenishing, and they even noticed when my napkin fell to the floor and brought me a new one right away.The food was excellent. My dining partner and I each had the same thing: a beautiful amuse bouche of a cold cucumber and corn soup, perfectly prepared foie gras appetizer, and prime rib "for two" carved table-side. The foie gras was tasty, and the prime rib was flavorful, tender, and well seasoned over all. My sorbets after dinner were excellent, tart (I had pear, pineapple, and a flavor I can't remember). The food was even better than I had expected, which says a lot given the hype I have heard via newspapers, zagat, and word of mouth.Now, there is a reason I didn't give this place a perfect rating. It was just a little bit slow. The service was precise, thoughtful and crisp, but the pace of the meal was a just a tad "French" to me -- meaning, once we were seated, it took a few minutes for anyone to come take our order for cocktails and a bottle of wine. Once we made our order for a bottle of wine, we "muscled" into ordering something else.All in all, this was a great place to eat. I will certainly return in the near future. Despite its minor shortcomings, this place is a real winner!--WEM

Chapeau! is by far my favorite French restaurant in San Francisco. My family has been eating there for close to 8 years now and I love the personal attention we receive from Philippe, restaurant's the owner, chef, host, sommelier, etc. Make sure to get a kiss good night from him before you leave or he will chase you down the block!As everyone has already mentioned, their prix fixe menu is a total steal considering the quality of the food, but I personally enjoy the slower pace of the meal when the eat later in the evening than the cheaper earlier sitting. Plus, you have more time to digest every delicious morsel!Whenever you decide to go, consider ordering the French onion soup, the cassoulet, whatever lamb dish they are serving, the steak frites, the foie gras salad, and you MUST MUST MUST order the profiterolles for dessert. I have dreams about the contrasting texture of their crispy shell and the creamy chocolate sauce and ice cream.I also highly recommend the palate cleansers and bringing your own wine, just so Philippe will come try a glass with your table!
Chapeau! has been a favorite of mine almost since they opened -- nearly 15 years ago.I have never been able to figure out how Philippe and Ellen turn out the quality of food that they do for the exceptional low price. It is AMAZING.I love the desserts -- the chocolate/banana cake! The white nut-filled dessert!So -because I have loved Chapeau! for so many years...it hurts to say this, but I am going to write it in the hope that Philippe reads it.  First of all, the service has always been spotty. When everyone was thrown in like sardines in the old place, you felt that there was an excuse. But it's the same in the new locations and, I believe it is getting worse. Example: I was in a couple of months ago -- late on a weeknight, and the place was more than half empty, so busy-ness not an excuse. Brought a friend who had never been in for a glass of wine, dessert, coffee. He knew that I love the place and the owners and had been coming for years. I almost had to stand up on the table and shout to even get a glass of wine (Ellen was talking with some patron, the maitre d' and waiters were oblivious). Also, the way the front people dress sets the tone for the restaurant and I think they need to raise the bar a bit. Being The Richmond doesn't have much in the way of restaurants with any style -- and I think that's an important niche that Chapeau! has filled. You used to be able to dress up a bit to go to Chapeau. But being greeted by someone who looks like they have been scrubbing floors doesn't really tend to encourage that.  I have only once in my long association with the restaurant taken advantage of the Early Bird Special. Some friends were coming up from San Jose and made a huge effort to get here in time to make it . We looked at the menu and there were scallops as starters...and we asked if it might be possible to get them as an entree. The maitre d' smiled and winked and said "oh, for you, of course I can!" NO mention of any extra charge. when the bill came, there was a significant extra charge that wiped out all the Early Bird savings...and other things were suspicious. I asked about the charge for the scallops and was told "oh no, no...had to charge extra." Because we were in a hurry, because I was with friends I rarely see, because I had said it was one of my favorite restaurants, because Philippe was not there, and because have been a customer for so many years and think of them as friends, I did not want to get into a further "discussion" and let it go. I have always LOVED Chapeau and sent so many people there, introduced so many people to the restaurant...so to have that happen left me with a very bitter taste in my mouth...and wondering if perhaps "games" are played if Philippe is not around. Also -- it would help if he would get bartenders who have some personality! There was a tall guy with glasses in there for awhile who was personable -- but the rest of them add nothing behind the bar. Philippe has all the personality in the world - why doesn't he get a bartender who has some sparkle and social skills? It could make a huge difference (not, of course, that he's lacking business..!)Again -- I have loved Chapeau! for many years -- so I hope with all my heart that they will thrive for another 15 years! I just might as well tell the truth in the hopes that these things are addressed.

We came here on the recommendation of all the Yelp reviews and were not disappointed. The ambiance and decor of the restaurant is just alright, some of the tables seemed too tightly packed together but since we went on a weekday we didn't need to sit right next to any other parties. The service was great though, very attentive and informative without being too intrusive. As many people have noted, the owner made a point of coming by and helping us choose a bottle of wine. I loved that he made 2 suggestions - one low-end and one high-end in price with compliments for both . We ended up going with the cheaper bottle and were very pleased.On to the food - we started with the oysters, foie gras, and sweetbreads. The oysters were pretty standard, but the foie gras was really yummy. There were 2 large slabs seared on top of a little piece of cake with raspberry sauce and fresh raspberries on the plate. The sweetbreads were as good as they could be for me, because the whole idea and texture just creeps me out. I think my boyfriend enjoyed them though. For dinner, I had the seared duck breast and he had the lamb shank. Both of them were really awesome. The duck was cooked just right with lots of flavor and juiciness. It was served with a risotto that was creamy with healthy additions of pulled duck meat as well. The lamb shank was huge but slowly cooked so that the meat was tender and just fell off the bone.We will definitely think about going back to Chapeau again. The prices are very reasonable, and the food extremely well-done. Perfect choice if you're looking for a place to have good food, wine, and conversation without breaking the bank!

However, it seems that you can't have great food and good service at a reasonable price. One of the three must suffer, and at Chapeau it is the service. Things started a little slow, but we were well on track to make the movie when our appetizers were done and entrees brought. The people at the next table, seated about 20 minutes after us, already had dessert menus in their hands, but we were enjoying the experience and not yet worried. A half hour after our entree plates were cleared, when we still hadn't seen a dessert menu or our waiter, we were starting to get a little irritated. After flagging down another staff person to request a dessert menu, our waiter brought the menu. Had we not ordered the prix fixe menu, we would have skipped dessert, but since we were paying for it we wanted it. The waiter acknowledged that he thought we had already ordered desert, but did not apologize in any way. Then, he disappeared for another 15 or 20 minutes, so we couldn't even order. We requested the check when we finally ordered dessert, and stressed that we were now running late for other plans. After finishing dessert, we again asked for the check, which was eventually brought to us in a cute little hat. I immediately put a credit card in the hat and tried to hand it back to the waiter. Needless to say, we missed our movie.I find it hard to believe that a restaurant with service this poor can survive in the city. I told him about the experience, he said that he was sorry and hoped that I would return. Unless they do something to assure that my next experience is not the same, that is doubtful. Good food only goes so far.

After writing a few reviews about new things for me I turn to a favorite place that I've returned to time and again for the past ten years, Chapeau! I first came here as a postdoc. A low salary and flexible schedule enabled me to take advantage of the early prix-fixe special. Years later I still come back for the prime time meals. Phillipe and his wife are the driving force behind this restaurant. I've never been disappointed with the food here. Their passion for the place is apparent in every bite. In addition to the classic French dishes, like my deliciously fresh frisee salad with fingerling potato chip bits and duck confit, there's an occasional modern creation, like the wonderful basil napoleon I had for dessert. Impeccably fresh delicious fruit with crisp thin puff pastry in an intensely green basil infused sauce. But how to keep the basil sauce green?? The sauce was clearly syrup based, and lacks the oil that keeps pesto bright green. We had to ask Philipe what the trick was, so when he bade us farewell after the meal, we inquired about the color of the sauce. Engaging Phillipe in a discussion about cooking techniques opened a floodgate of knowledge and artistic passion. Phillipe explained the basil leaves must be blanched quickly first and then incorporated into the sauce cold and strained. Phillipe also revealed many of his other talents from the musical to his role in the design of his restaurant logo.  Chapeau! also has an excellent wine selection for a relatively small restaurant. We had a bottle of a 2005 vintage from Gigondas, the year of a visit to the region in Provence and the wine brought back happy memories of the trip for our table. Finally, they threw in a complementary dessert, a delicious apple tart with carmel and hazelnut ice cream. My dinner here was roughly half the price of a meal at the Dining Room at the Ritz or Coi or any of the other super premiere restaurants, but to me, is equally satisfying or more. Phillipe is an artist, Chapeau! is his studio, and he runs it with the warmth of his heart. Thanks Phillipe! Five stars are gladly given for a personal touch and excellent food.note: this bistro is at times a pretty loud, boisterous place - over the years I've noticed more groups that come to Chapeau! for big events. Big groups in the small space = loud atmosphere, so don't expect a place where you can whisper to each other.

Chapeau! is apparently french for "Wow!" ... I can't think of a more appropriate name. This place is so subdued, for lack of a better word, from the outside that I would never have found this place without Yelp and all the positively glowing reviews on it. And here I am, writing one of my own! I had pretty high expectations walking in because of the high rating here, but I was still pleasantly surprised. As we walked inside, my first impression of the dining room is that it was neat and unassuming, with colors in soothing neutral tones. It's not fancy, but it's not supposed to be---it's a bistro! It's a small space, packed fairly tightly with tables. Philippe, the owner / chef, greeted my friend and me as we came in, shaking our hands and welcoming us, which was a pleasant indication of the quality of service, I thought. Having arrived just before 6pm, we were able to order from the early bird 3 course. We were surprised by the number of things to choose from (4 choices each for appetizers, entrees, and desserts) for a "cheapo" ($25) early meal. We were treated to a complimentary chilled melon soup. It was very refreshing... a little minty and had a bit of a gingery kick. For our appetizer, we both ordered the brie thing... it's basically a blob of melted brie on top of a potato hash thing, on top of some apples and greens, and a raspberry(?) sauce. A food writer I will never be, so sorry for my lack of... articulation. Anyway, that thing was FANTASTIC and definitely our favorite course of the evening. Next, I had the duck breast over polenta and my friend had mussels with a side of [very yummy crispy crunchy] fries, which were both very good entrees in their own right, but the brie blobby thing was a tough act to follow! For dessert, I had the creme brulee, which was very good, but I really haven't met a creme brulee I didn't like, and it is hard to mess up. My friend had the basil napolean. I had a small taste and it was a very interesting combination of flavors. Basically, it looked like four very thin wafers arranged on top of a sweet basil sauce with chopped of bits of fruit. There was also a thicker, yellowy-orange colored sauce in the middle but I didn't try any of that.The food was excellent and creatively prepared as far as I can tell, though I admit that I am not extremely knowledgable about french food. The service was also excellent: prompt and attentive, with none of the snobbery I expected from a French place. The bill came in a hat, which I thought was weird and admittedly cute, since chapeau also means hat.After the lovely dinner, we made it out the door before Philippe chased us down, called us mademoiselles (heehee), and thanked us for coming! He did the cute little cheek air kissing thing that made me feel all sophisticated. Yes, I don't interact with European people often. Anyway, can't say I've been chased down outside of a restaurant by an owner to be thanked before. Such a simple gesture, but it made us feel like a million bucks.I can't remember the last time I've been so satisfied with a dining experience or treated with such genuine warmth. I am not the least bit surprised to note that a lot of the people in the restaurant seemed to be return customers. Needless to say, I'll be going back.
dinner on a saturday with the hubby, reservations for 8pm, mother's day weekend (appeared to be lots of people there celebrating all kinds of stuff). street parking was not easy, but anticipated. cute place, and tables are packed close together (like an inch away from the table for 2 next to us), but this is no surprise in SF. overall, really enjoyed the food and fully intend to go back to try more.seated immediately by the hostess - very pleasant woman. chef came around to greet us, and took our wine order - unexpected, but appreciated (he was all around checking on everyone all night). we opted for the 4 course menu @ 46pp, w/ wine & extras, bill came to ~200+ w/ tip.the goods:- amuse bouche: cauliflower soup - just a small cup with some truffle oil on top. great start.- choice appts: foie gras (special +$) & mesclun salad. if you love foie gras, you must try. very delish. and portion was bigger than i expected for a french restaurant (i would've eaten more had there been more!).- tasting fish: scallop over risotto. there's cheese in the risotto (i'm generally not a fan of cheese), flavors went well and scallop was cooked perfect. this was not a part of the 3 course menu or part of the regular menu, and happy to have tried it.- choice entre: prime rib for 2 (special +$). the server brings out this BIG piece of meat on the bone, plus 2 bones with marrow, on a cutting board to show you, then he sets up on a table near you and starts slicing the meat off the bone and plates it for the two. presentation was nice. came with scalloped potatoes (we didn't touch) and warmed/wilted spinich (tasted good). shockingly, too much food. i asked to take the left overs home (yes, *cringe*), but the meat was so tasty, and we had so much left, i could not leave it behind!- choice dessert: lemon tarte (special) & profiteroles. lemon tarte was really good. profiteroles were good, but would try something else next time.and like any good french restaurant, you need to ask for your bill when you are ready (you're not automatically given the bill when THEY *think* you're ready - silly americans...).service was very good, but not as attentive as i hoped. e.g., after the hostess seated us and the chef served us wine, we waited awhile before our waiter even greeted us; we didn't get glasses of water under after we ordered; the bread came with the amuse bouche; we sat with empty wine glasses during our meal (*gasp!*). but i will also say that it looked like a very busy night, and the waiter was on the move the whole night. regardless, we were not regulars (but hope to be) and i got the distinct impression familiar faces were treated with just a bit more attention. (hope to get that treatment next time we go!)

This bistro's menu helpfully points out the curious linguistic oddity that the word "chapeau" in French means "hat", but if you stick an exclamation point at the end of it, it means "the city's most unexpectedly awesome French bistro on 22nd & Clement that will unfailingly get you laid if you take a date here". French is such an expressive language!

AMAZING! We were a little apprehensive at first, as this was our first time dining at an upscale french restaurant and we weren't quite sure what to expect. This all disappeared, however, from the moment we walked in the door and were greeted by the effusive chef. The excellent service continued even after we were seated....our waiter provided several helpful suggestions on meal choices and wine parings. As for the meal itself, we went with the 3-course price fix option. For appetizers, we got the tiger prawns and blue cheese tart. They were both fantastic, but the prawns were the clear favorite. Afterwards, we were presented a small cup of cauliflower soup that was surprisingly flavorful. Our main courses consisted of the petit poussin and the bouillabaisse. The poussin was excellent, but oh man, the bouillabaisse was to die for. It might be one of the best dishes I've ever had. We finished with the chocolate cake and basil neapolitan for dessert (sweet and refreshing). Towards the end of our meal, the chef sat down at the table next to us, as his night was finishing. He made it a point to ask us how our meal was, and wished us well as we left (he even hugged and kissed me goodbye). In short, Chapeau! is a memorable dining experience....every dish we tried was seasoned to perfection, which is not the case at most other restaurants we've been to. Give this place a try...you won't be disappointed.

Oui! Oui! Oui! Get thee to Chapeau--and look out Thomas Keller.  Do NOT miss the orange soup for dessert-- a truly fresh pairing of citrus, mint, and cream and nuts that will blow your mind. Just when you think you've thought of everything--oranges and mint? Last weekend's meal included fois gras with a lovely Sauternes (by the half glass I might add--how very French to allow us to manage portion size!).  My boyfriend is a native and fellow budget gourmet, he swears by the place. My good opinion was sealed when Phillipe not only didn't recommend the most expensive bordeaux to accompany our meal but a less expensive Chateau Neuf du Pape (decanted I might add--when is the last time your local restaurant went to the trouble to decant your half bottle of wine?), but he then ran down the block to catch us and say good night because he'd missed us when we left.Update: Just visited last night for Easter. The Prime Rib ("cote d boef") rocked my world. Best meat I have ever had, served with four sauces and the world's best haricots verts (green beans), and potatoes au gratin. Special thanks to the Chapeau staff for decanting several bottles of special wine we brought for the occasion and not making us feel "cheap" when we wanted to do our own vertical. I continue to pray that television shows like Rachel Ray will stop directing tourists here so that us locals can keep the place to ourselves. :::sigh::: but Phillipe's food and style are so wonderful I can't help but wish him all the best. And...the orange soup was back on the menu last night, again capping off literally, the best meal I ever ate. Also felt that he should have poured more wine when he saw our glasses were empty. (No, we're not high maintenance--this is what we've grown accustomed to at other, comparably-priced restaurants. -     The escargot was soaked in butter/herb sauce--this is traditional, but seemed extra rich, for some reason; the rack of lamb was cooked appropriately, but my husband did have to add a dash of salt; and crme brulee was very good. -     The foie gras was good and portion size was what you'd expect, but the reduction it came with was a tad to sweet for me--almost like a caramel sauce rather than a reduction; the roasted duck breast, accompanied by polenta and grapes, was good, but the polenta was bland. No real complaints other than wishing the skin was more browned--and aesthetically, it wasn't at all appealing or pretty because there wasn't a lot of color on the plate (no green or red, only browns).-     Also agree w/the other Yelper that the resto is very "old world French;" so if that's what you like, then you may enjoy it here.Overall, we walked out disappointed and very perplexed as to why the resto is rated so highly by other Yelpers.

This place is average. That's it, no more, no less. The prices, on the other hand, are a bit above average, in my opinion, for what you get - except for the wine list, which had numerous reasonably priced options. First, starting with the atmosphere - it was too bright and looked somewhat like a wedding reception, rather than a cute, intimate French restaurant. Lowering the side lighting, turning off the overhead track lighting, and putting some candles on the table would do wonders for this place. Second, as others have noted, the tables are very close together. Fine, that's how it is in France. But, they need to do something about the noise. We kept joking that we were going to call each other on our cell phones because we couldn't hear each other talking across the table.Now on to the food. The brie - potato starter was tasty, but was a little on the sweet side (there was pear or something in there, too). It would have been very, very good had the main vegetarian course not been sweet, too. While also tasty, the raisins, the carmelized garnish (like you get in the top of an ice cream) made the veggie dish too sweet (with not enough salt), especially after having a starter that bordered on overly sweet. The filet mignon was apparently good (or so I was told), but nothing overly exceptional. The service was ok, although they screwed up one of the starters and forgot to bring a napkin to replace a dropped one after I asked twice. All in all, an average dinner at above average prices. I doubt I'll go back since there are so many other great French restaurants in the city (think L'Ardoise).
If I could only use a single word to describe this place, it would be "utterly charming". Well, make that two words. My point is that this is a restaurant that serves palate-pleasing, updated French food and is run by the nicest team of people. The restaurant is a little hard to find, as the name plate has fallen off and the owner has not felt compelled to replace it. But with 492+ reviews on Yelp and counting, he doesn't need to advertise. This restaurant's reputation for serving quality French fare in a cozy, comfortable atmosphere has already spread like wild fire.

Adding to the list. Two of us, with reservations. Yes, the two-tops are close together but we've lived in Manhattan, yes, it was noisy, but really that's not a problem in a busy restaurant. By the middle of the entrees (bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin, parsnip puree, spinach, apple-calvados sauce for me, filet mignon, trompe-de-morts mushrooms, potatoes for the bf), we were trying to place where this fit on the list of best restaurant meals we'd had since 1971. The $38 prix-fixe three course menu is almost miraculous, and explains why the restaurant was crowded in the current economy. Also, two of the absolute best dishes we've ever had: my Mesclun Salad with Crme Dijonnaise, Red Seedless Grapes, Pistachio, Fried Camembert & Walnut Bread; his dessert-- Nuage de Noix: Roasted Pistachios, Almonds & Hazelnuts in a Frozen Chantilly & Italian Meringue. Intelligent and intelligently-priced wine list too.The service was excellent, the maitresse d'hotel took VERY good care of us, checking on the table frequently (and all her other tables as well), and I can't compliment the chef, Philippe, enough for his graciousness. He came to the table twice, once to thank us for our business and once to thank us again (we had never been there before) as we were leaving. I told him that Chapeau! reminded me, for those of you who remember the restaurant scene in San Francisco in the 1970s, of Chez Michel and he was especially pleased because it turns out he knows and admires Michel.We will never visit San Francisco again without dining at least once at Chapeau!

I have to say that this is one occasion where perhaps I shouldn't have read the yelp reviews of Chapeau! prior to eating there. Given the nearly unanimously stellar reviews, it was with very high expectations that I dined at this outer Richmond favorite. Needless to say , I was very much let down. First off, when you first walk into the place you enter a closet sized curtained enclosure where you are expected to wait for your table. This we did with another couple. It felt like all four of us were playing seven minutes in heaven except it was more like 10 minutes and there was no making out. Thats pretty minor for me, I'm not a big complainer...just pointing it out. As for the service...It was all very much well-intentioned I suppose, but it was all over the place. Similar to reviewer andy, we literally had about four different waiters, none of whom paid any real attention to us. Then there is Phillipe...Highly touted for his signature "french" kisses. Again I agree with Andy in that the whole thing seems kind of gimmicky now. When we left we were about a block away when I hear running from behind...I swear I thought I was getting rolled on by gangstas. Sure enough it was Phillipe, as promised, with the kisses. The worst part of the whole evening for me ,though , had to do with the wine service. After laboring to find the perfect Bordeaux for the night, Phillipe comes over and presents the bottle to my date. "What's this?" I ask myself..."could Phillipe be mistaken about who ordered (and who's paying)?" I mean after all I think it was the busboy who took my wine order so its very possible. Phillipe continues to pour the taster for my date, who at this point is equally baffled, and then pours himself a small glass. He toasts my date as they both sip the wine and I stare in disbelief. I cant imagine anyone who doesn't know that the person who ordered always taste first before the guest is served. And that he poured himself a taste?!?!?.. Don't get me wrong if he had employed the proper serving method I would have gladly poured him a healthy glass. But it was almost as if he wanted to pull the whole "smooth french guy hitting on the american dude's chick" thing.  That little move really turned me off from the beginning.The food...yeah its good, but not nearly as good as the reviews suggest. I can't claim any expertise on french food, but what we had was enjoyable. Mussels, brie, cassoulet, filet mignon and creme brulee...All as part of the prix fixe deal, which is quite reasonable. I would recommend trying Chapeau! if you live in the area, but certainly do not travel far for it.

The Foie Gras is amazing as is the salmon.Main courses - all of the fish/chicken dishes we've had are excellent. I would avoid the prime rib unless you like prime rib with a steak texture - it's not a prime rib and is sliced/served like a steak. It actually resembled tri tip in presentation. Not bad but for good prime rib hit House of Prime Rib!Desserts are again creative and wonderful.The wine list is excellent too - the owner is great for recommending a perfect wine to pair with your meal. He was absent the day we were there.Downside - small - not intimate small. It's always overcrowded, so not a great place for any intimacy or private conversation as the next table is literally on top of you. Wait staff try to negotiate but you do get bumped alot and the tables are not generous if you're in a large party. Recently there with a party of 10 (final bill right under $1K - with champagne/wine) and we had to keep asking to have plates removed as there literally was no room . The prime rib serves two - served beautifully - comes on a plate, the side of potatoes and green beans each get their own, and the three sauces are presented in small cups on a plank. Add in bread, water glass, wine glass, butter dish, bread plate - there is literally no real estate left on the table!
What a great evening we had celebrating an anniversary this week end at Chapeau!. The food, service, wine list, ambience all exceptional. Every dish was attended to with thought and attention to preparation.
We have been regulars of this place for about 2 years now. We go every month (sometimes twice a month) and have never been disappointed by the food, the attentive service, and by Phillipe and Ellen's charm and hospitality. To the foolhardy, don't let Chapeau's cozy location in the Richmond or lack of "big-name reputation" fool you. Most locals know how good this place is so don't expect to get a table without a reservation well in advance. With that said, this place is one of the best deals in town. Their prix-fixe dinner is $35 per person and the quality and service truly match the big boys around town. We highly recommend the porcini-crusted sweetbreads and any game meat that Philippe decides to make, you will NOT be disappointed! I hope this place lasts forever.

The ambiance at Clementine is better, and they have the foie gras on the regular menu, instead of as a special.The only course I didn't like was the tasting fish, which was the day boat scallops. Not very original or flavorful. However, everything else was excellent. The lamb shank was so tender and huge. Filet mignon was in a wonderful truffled sauce with diced mushrooms, very good. If it's just 2 people, go to Clementine, but if it's 4 or more, go to Chapeau.

I don't claim to be an expert on French cuisine, but I did like Chapeau! It's a cute, cozy little place, but It does get a bit loud at peak hours when the restaurant is packed. We were greeted warmly by the owner/chef when we were seated, and were served warm bread and butter, as well as a complimentary chilled melon soup to cleanse the palate. As for the food, the portions were moderately-sized but also moderately-priced. I actually prefer smaller portions because I hate coming home feeling like I'm about to pass out from a food coma, and the amount of food at this place seemed just right. For $38 (a 3-course meal package) I had a duck salad appetizer (though beware the liver on-top if you're not adventurous...), a monk-fish entree over veggies and lobster bisque which was delicious, and fresh 3-flavor sorbet for dessert. As we left the owner/chef bid us farewell individually with a kiss on both cheeks. It was a fun night!

Every month or so I get a craving for traditional French Bistro fare - escargot, French onion soup, steak frittes... With all the great reviews on yelp, I decided to make Chapeau next on the list for a bistro buzz. Reservations are a must, and we went at 6:15 on a Friday evening. We were nearly the first customers, and the place was freezing. We kept our coats, and so did everyone else at the first seating.  The atmosphere is key to me when enjoying the comforts of bistro dining, and this is not what I had in mind. It was not any one thing, but the combination of all of them - the super close tables, the rushed service, and the freezing temperature - made us want to get out of there as soon as we finished eating. The food was ok - nothing special, but the main detraction was the service. This was not the casual take your time kind of bistro service and staff I'm used to, but rather hyper tense rushed get to your table to take the plate before you've finished type. I'm giving it 3 starts because the food was nothing to complain about either, but for a quiet, relaxing, bistro dinner, I would not recommend this place. P.S. The famous Philipe was nowhere to be found.

One of my most favorite places to dine in San Francisco. Phillipe and Ellen make you feel like you're welcome (Phillipe makes a point of kissing every woman in the place!), and the service here is excellent, even when the place is jumping, as usually happens on a Sunday between 5:00 p.m. and about 8 p.m. when all the "early bird" diners are there.Speaking of early birds, the early bird special dinner, which is in effect Sunday through Thursday from 5 to 6 p.m. only is not to be missed. It is by far the best food value in San Francisco. This is a three-course meal, with plenty to choose from, full-size portions for just $24 per person. Add about $18 for a half bottle of nice French red wine (full bottles can be had for about twice that), and you have a great meal for two with wine, tax and tip for about $83.The food is consistently wonderful and suprising, even when I have the same things again. The soups are to die for, as are most of the appetizers. I had the warm brie and potato thingy (can't remember the actual name) while my wife had the chestnut soup, which had a hint of curry. The salmon is always excellent, and the portion is huge. I had the pork loin, which was out of this world. My wife have raved about the mussels. The only disappointment for me is the cassoulet, which is very rich and gets tiresome after a few bites.Every times we've been there, Ellen always brings us a third dessert to try, and of course who can refuse?! But don't miss the sorbets.Make a day of it. Tour San Francisco, visit the Fine Arts Museum (Legion of Honor) and listen to the organ recital there, and then head out to Chapeau!

Chapeau is up there for best service in the city, on top of that, the food is wonderful too. There are so many mid to upper level restaurants in San Francisco that don't seem to give a hoot about providing the customer with truly professional service. Chapeau is the exception! You feel welcome and taken care of from the moment you walk in the door to the moment you leave. The menu is wonderful and I've literally never had a bad meal here. The other thing I noticed that was particularly impressive was that there were a few people eating alone at the bar. For some, especially women, the concept of eating alone in a Restaurant may be daunting, and to see that there were multiple women eating alone comfortably at the bar was impressive. The staff and the owner were considerate and attentive to everyone; their manners are impeccable, and in this day and age, that is something. You should not have to go to an inordinately expensive Restaurant to get professional service and a staff that takes making you happy seriously. If you're looking for a great meal at a reasonable price, served by a staff that is actually interested in your happiness, give Chapeau a try.

The complimentary amuse bouche, the super silky potatoe leek soup with crouton garnished with pesto in a demi-tasse cup set the tone for our wonderful French dinner punctuated by oohs and aahs. My choices were the corn soup with crab cake and white truffle oil (chef Philippe is a genius with soups!), mussels with fries (standard and broth slightly salty), the sweetbreads (rich and dark), and we as a table shared a bottle of La Follette Pinot Noir 2008 (so goood!!!), kir cocktails, and all the desserts expect for the sorbet trio (that's 8 desserts for 7 people). Hands down our favorites were the pistachio/nut semi-freddo like ice cream and the french toast, which we all agreed was probably the best we have ever had. Recommend next time getting the prime rib and bone marrow for two-sliced table side and beautifully presented and the seared foie gras. Everyone else also enjoyed the duck and Ahi Tuna salads, filet mignon, and the seared scallop was just one large scallop on a bed of risotto or something (didn't try it). Like all good places not all the dishes are spot on so I would go with raters reviews on what to order. Bon Appetit!
This place used to be one of those 'best kept secrets' in SF, as far as French restaurants go..It's gotten very popular over the last year, however the quality didn't suffer, and it's still one of the best neighborhood restaurants in the City. We've had many dinners here:  - the food is always great - the service is excellent and very personable - relaxing atmosphere makes the meal - location is very convenient, with plenty of parking (sure beats those trendy spots in the mission, where you spend an hour parking, an hour waiting and 45 min. eating)My only complaint (gotta have one, right?) is that it's hard to make a reservation these days because the restaurant has gotten so popular - that doesn't take away any stars though..If you truly appreciate French cuisine, you'll love this place!
I discovered this place because of Yelp and decided to take my mom there for her birthday. We made reservations online and wrote that there was a birthday. When I walked in, this Asian lady walked towards me mumbling something and I kind of moved out of the way because I thought she was trying to get out. It turns out that she was the hostess. The reason I thought she was a customer was because she was so poorly dressed. She was wearing this heather gray sweater, a pair of jeans, and black slippers with white socks. The outfit seriously looked like it was purchased at Walmart and I'm honestly not saying this to be funny. She also had no make-up on, her hair was a mess and she didn't even bother smiling. The only way that I can explain how this tore up looking woman is the hostess is that she must be the chef/owner's wife because I seriously doubt anyone else would get away looking like that. Everyone else, including the bus boys, looked a million times better than this woman. Besides the angry homeless looking hostess, the service was pretty good. Our server, who I swear looked like the hostess's brother, was just OK but the bus boys were on top of everything and there was another guy who immediately took our drink orders even though he wasn't our server. The food, on the other hand, really wasn't that good. The presentation was excellent but the taste did not live up to the hype. The food was just mediocre and most definitely not worth the price. Also, I thought it was in really poor taste that no one acknowledged my mother's birthday. I mean, I'm not looking to get anything free, but whenever we make a reservation and we write that it's someone's birthday, the server always mentions it. A "oh I heard that it's someones birthday..." would have been nice. If I bothered mentioning it in the reservation, that should be a sign that I would like this fact to be acknowledged. Overall, this place is a pretentious wannabe Fleur de Lys/Viogner and have no business charging what they do. Needless to say, I will never be back. One star for the great staff excluding the hostess and her brother.

Excellent food and service, better than I've found at much pricier, trendier French restaurants. It's not the place if you want a uber-romantic atmosphere (because it's small and crowded) or if you want to wow someone with a fat, fat bill, but it's perfect if you want a bistro-like atmosphere and generous portions for very reasonable prices--without sacrificing quality! I absolutely loved this restaurant! Came here for my graduation dinner with family, made reservations about a week in advance. The earliest time they had available was 8, so we went there at 8. Upon arriving, I noticed the restaurant was crowded (and was so glad I made the reservations). Food was just amazing! It did take a little longer than I expected but I'll say it was worth the wait! I had the fish, and it was yummy! While we waited, we were able to eat bread and butter, which was really great for me since I absolutely love bread, and they had the European butter, which is just heaven when combining the two. Dessert was just as amazing. We had creme brulee, the orange soup (which was better than I thought it would be) and the sorbet. I really loved the creme brulee even though I felt full I just couldn't help but to savor the dessert. They give your bill in a lovely hat (quite unique and interesting) and upon walking out, they thanked us for coming and gave the French goodbye greeting. I can't rate the price (my parents paid the bill and I don't recall the prices for our meal) but the quality was definitely A plus. Overall an amazing experience for me.
