Just returned from my birthday dinner at Chapeau! How is it that we've lived in the Outer Richmond for three years and never stumbled into this place before? My husband gets big points for finding this place.The restaurant was romantic and special without being pretentious. My wine glass was always full, my water glass was always full - but somehow the servers slipped in and out without really disturbing our conversation, I love that. I recognized one of the waiters from The Richmond - he said he's worked both places - he is great - just friendly enough, knowledgeable - we like him.The food. Wow! Okay, we've been to Paris several times and our brother-in-law is French, so we know French food. This is exceptional. In my humble opinion, this is the best French food outside of Paris. Portions are generous - the scallops and risotto were perfect, the pork tender loin was perfectly cooked and tender. Our appetizer salads were ample - I hate it when you order a salad and you get three leaves of lettuce and a crouton. Desserts didn't disappoint either.This place is great for a special occasion, but not so pricey that you can't go more often - we'll be going more often, I can guarantee that!! And, the owner did track us down on the side walk afterward to make sure we were happy. Nice touch!! When we told him that we loved it, he said "you have good taste!" Make a reservation, what are you waiting for?

speak of overrated. is the french food scene in such bad shape here in SF? folks you're killing me... okay. maybe it's just me. but here's my story and it might counterbalance some of the reviews. i was looking for a relaxed place to eat some downhome french food, possibly in a slightly hip place, and the reviews seemed to indicate that. what i got was a place that reeked of "under the tuscan sun". a tired act by the main dude with mandatory cheek kisses. i mean, i'm european. i don't kiss people who come to my restaurant. neither does any restaurateur, in paris or elsewhere. it's forced. four different waiters waited on us, neither with any idea about our preferences that we had expressed to each of the prior waiters. and then, to crown it off... the couples smacking of illicit affair (but in a said way, not in a hot bordello way). and the hat for the check! my god, please, somebody tell them it's so gauche it's not even funny even if it's meant ironically. (the very expression "chapeau!" in french sounds about as hip as "gee-whiz", by the way). the food. my mouth watered all the way there after reading the online menu. but... there was no brandade, there was no chestnut soup, they were out of a few of the dishes. the rest was fine, i mean, it was fine, solid, slightly inventive food that would have done equally well without the inventiveness. and it's in the middle of nowhere. now if it were on 22 + valencia, i'd say i'd stop by once in a while, but why on earth is someone going to drive across town (regarldess of where you live) to go to clement street to be treated to air-kisses and a check in a hat? oh, man.

Place has so many great reviews that it doesn't need mine to boost its star count, but what the hell, I'll get on the bandwagon. Best bargain in the city. I can't think of a single other place where you can get French food like this for under forty bucks. AND they have an early bird special for people who eat between 5 and 6. Look, it may not be super creative, but it is consistently excellent, and sometimes you don't want chefs messing around with exotic ingredients. Decided at the last minute to go here after shopping in downtown SF. We had eaten here once before about 3 years ago and really liked it. Called and asked for a reservation and were told we could sit at the bar. We took it and arrived about 30 minutes later (6:00 p.m. on a Sunday--place was packed). We were promptly seated (only disappointment was a table for two was open the entire time we were there and it would have been nice to sit at a table). My wife and I both ordered the 3 course Prix Fixe and a half bottle of a very good Zinfandel. Before our meal arrived we were given samplers of a Cauliflower soup that was very good--nice touch to what would prove to be a great meal. For my first course I had the Salade Landais which was a Frisee salad with Duck Confit and smoked duck and little potato chips. It may have been the best salad I have ever eaten. I didn't want it to end. My wife had the Mesclun salad which featured Fried Camembert. It too was outstanding. For our main course, I had the Baby Poissin in an a delicious sauce with baby potatoes, onions, and mushrooms. This may have been the best chicken dish I have eaten. Nice portion and delicious. My wife the Cassoulet with two different kinds of Sausage, Duck Confit, Cannelini beans and loved it. Also a very good portion. For dessert my wife had the Lemon Tart which she loved and I had the French Toast with Hazelnut Ice Cream and Caramel sauce. This takes 15 minutes to prepare but worth the wait. It was nice to rest a little and it was delicious. Our waitress was the bartender who was very busy but still managed to pay attention to our needs. She is an excellent bartender and took very good care of us. In addition to how good the food was, the presentation of everything was really done well. I really enjoyed this place three years ago but enjoyed it even more this time. We will be back sooner than three years from now.

If you routinely have French food, you'll like this place. If you've never tried French cuisine, you'll still like this place. Chapeau delivers tasty French dishes at an affordable price.The space is tiny but warm. The owner is exceptional, well-known for his farewell kisses. The service is a bit slow on the weekends.
Chapeau occupies a very small space that is full of tables touching each other. It feels cramped and overcrowded. We were four for dinner on Saturday night. Two of us came a few minutes before the rest of the party. When you open the door your enter a small space enclosed by black curtains. A woman peeked in, asked for details and told us to wait in that claustrophobic, dark space. After a few minutes in pitch dark we ventured in and were ordered to go stand in the back of the small room, next to the two bathrooms and the table where uncorking bottles is done. There, everybody going into the kitchen or the bathrooms had the opportunity to bump into us. In the meantime, the rest of our party had come and finally we were shown to a window table where two could have chairs and two could sit on the window sill with drafty winds and the narrow ledge adding to the discomfort. But you want to know about the food. OK, it's reasonably priced and some of it is good. You can have three and four course menus. The wine list is nice and they have half glasses so you can mix and match. I had a lovely smoked trout salad, a pedestrian black cod and a trio of sorbets. My table-mates liked their oysters and lamb. The service is sometimes inattentive and sometimes incomprehensible. My dessert wine tasted like it had probably been in an open bottle since its vintage year (2003).When we were leaving we asked to have a cab called and were told to go down to Geary Street where we could catch a cab.To sum - the good food is dwarfed by the discomfort of seating, the overcrowding and the uneven service. You don't have to put up with this. There are hundreds of better placed in SF.

The rain arrived after we left this place...and it didn't put a damper on the evening at all. It's SF, so you should expect wind & rain, followed by warm autumn days, followed by 4 mos. of fog during this time of year. Chapeau itself is a remarkable little place out in the Richmond district that reminds you why you should eat out more often. Remarkable because it's a tiny neighborhood bistro headed by a passionate chef/owner who greets every single one of the diners appreciatively and seems to have a loyal following in an area of the City that changes constantly. The dinner menu is French of course but with a hint of Cali. The basket of warm baguettes was constantly refilled, as were the water glasses. We did the prix fixe menu cuz that's just how we roll & cuz it's a tad cheaper. Appetizers consisted of a slightly sweet corn soup topped with crab meat and a sweetbread surrounded by mushrooms, slathered in its own perfect deep brown sauce. When asked how I wanted my salmon cooked, i hesitated 'cuz i've never been asked that before...pretty unusual, i thought. The pleasantly surprising smoky flavor won me over, but i think the cilantro pesto was unnecessary. I'm still trying to figure out whether the Lady enjoyed her monkfish (she seemed puzzled by the texture), although I'm guessing she did by the near empty plate. Loved the extensive drink menu and how they break it down price-wise for the wine bottles. The desserts (profiterolles and a tarte grand-mere) were the exclamation point to our meals. I can't say enough about the service, nor the food or even the place itself--I'll just have to keep coming back.

dear lord, the sweetbreads were amazing.for 3 entrees, 2 appetizers, a half bottle of wine, 2 desserts, a coffee and a glass of muscato: $160, incl tax/tipwe had:appetizers: half dozen oysters, onion soup (deliciously cheesy)entrees: sweetbreads (life-changing), duck medallions, and a stew i couldn't pronounce, but it was really, really richdesserts: chocolate cake (good, but really too rich to end a meal with. if you want it and not want to feel too full afterwards, try to eat lighter during the meal), basil napoleon (fruity and really unique)we went on saturday to the early seating, around 5:45 p.m. i would totally recommend going as early as possible because then you can choose where you want to sit (provided that it is the same number of seats your reserved for). as a party of 2, we were able to sit in the back right corner with more space instead of stuck in the middle of two other parties of 2 (which kinda feels like an informal party of 6, from what i could see)so, yes, its a little cramped, and yes, the black curtain is confusing (i was looking for another entrance after i ran into it and no one came to get me), but, dear lord, the sweetbreads changed my life.
easily one of the best (if not THE best) adult meal we had in our life to date. phillipe made us feel like PRINCESSES the whole night! we went on a weekend when it was busy and people had driven out from afar just to get to their reservations on time since phillipe was to be on vacation soon, and yet he still made room for a bunch of knuckleheads like us who didn't make reservations. everything we ate that night exceeded our expectations, plate after plate after plate. the three course meal was DIVINE, even more so when you get to pick each one of your courses. the tomato bisque was the best I have ever had, the complimentary amuse bouche of melon soup had a little kick to it which was very tasty, the filet was cooked perfectly and i literally scraped the plate to get every last bit of sauce, and as full as i was, i tackled my warm chocolate cake and ate most of the giant creme brulee as it was too good not to eat. he even gave us another dessert on the house, so we had four amongst us. it was definitely a feast for over 2 hours that night and was fabulous!i've also never received such warm and kind customer service. every staff member, including phillipe and his wife, came to our table to ask how our meal was and were very attentive to us even when it was beyond 10pm on a sunday night. even after we left, phillipe sprinted outside to hug and kiss each one of us and say thank you. it was adorable and extremely kind!the food, customer service, quality, prices, and ambiance truly live up to the restaurant's name & deserves every high praise he's received. a modest gem in the city, totally unexpected when you're passing by a restaurant that has a handwritten sign of it's name on 8.5x11 paper.

First off, the food is amazing but my gripe isn't about the food but more about the atmosphere. Tonight I went to Chapeau! looking forward to delicious french food like I normally have had in the past. Instead of enjoying my meal in peace and quiet, my partner and I were confront with a very noisy child with his parents and grandparents next to us. While I think some restaurants are appropriate for kids, this one is certainly not one of them. If I am paying $$$ for a meal, I expect my meal to be delicious, services well attended to and quiet. I do not expect to be entertained by a loud shrill of a child especially at a french restaurant. I complained to the waiter at first but I could tell that he did not take me serious enough so I made my second complaint to the maitre d'. She told me that there was nothing she could do about it. Well actually there is.... she could either ask the parents to do something about their noisy child or as their yelp ad says remind the parents that their restaurant is not appropriate for kids. Sorry to say but it will be awhile before I come back to eat after this experience.

This restaurant is the little french restaurant engine that could! It's a little hard to find... we drove by it twice and missed it because it is in the middle of a residential area and the sign is not very large nor well-lit. Food quality is on par with La Folie and Fleur de Lys, but costs less, I was very pleased with all my courses. Service was great, you are greeted by the owner personally, which has never happened to me at any other restaurant in the city. (the owner even walks you out the door when you leave and kisses the ladies on the cheek for a genuine euro goodbye) Only gripe is the fact that they try to fit 50 tables in the size of an average living room, so yeah, you almost are rubbing shoulders with the other patrons and feel like they can hear everything you are saying. If they keep up the service and the quality of food, they will probably have no problems relocating and expanding in the future

I had heard very good things of this place, and decided to just drop in to see if we could get a table for 2. Luckily we were there early on a Saturday evening, and got a teeny table. The decor in the restaurant is really homey and elegant, and it really makes the small cramped tables seem that much less cramped. The service was impeccable, and table settings spotless. My friend and I felt underdressed, but the waitstaff did not treat us any differently. We ordered an appetizer of sweetbreads and I got a cassoulet and my friend got the duck leg. The amuse bouche and the breads were very good. The sweetbreads were fantastic and I felt the entrees were good, but not mind-blowing. What really made this place shine was the service. We got a friendly and enthusiastic handshake from the chef, our check in a cute little hat, and after we left, halfway down the street, the chef came running after us. We turned around and wondered if we had left something at the table or didn't leave a big enough tip. All he wanted was to properly say goodbye, and gave us both two kisses on the cheeks! Such a wonderful surprise, leaving us smiling for the rest of the evening.
I have been a true fan of Chapeau for years and wanted to try out Clementine after hearing they are owned by the same people. The food is just as tasty as Chapeau and that makes sense since the head chef manages both. The pluses was that Clementine was less crowded (there was actually space between the tables) resulting in less noise as well as less of a wait for food. The minus is that it is a bit more costly. So if you don't mind the noise level and wait, then Chapeau is more bang for your buck but be aware that I heard Chapeau's menu will or has changed so check for the new price. If you enjoy Chapeaus food and just prefer something less crowded and don't mind paying a little more for it, then Clementine is your choice. Either way, you can't go wrong. Both places serve very delicious French food at a price extremely lower than French Laundry and the staff are very professional and provide great service and the owners are very sweet people.

I was sorely disappointed in our dining experience at Chapeau! I picked the restaurant based on several people I knew who loved it, as well as on yelp reviews. The service was abysmal. We must have been waited on by three servers--I have no idea who our actual waitperson was. Of course, no one introduced themselves, so I really had no clue. I usually don't drink a lot of water when I'm at dinner, but I did this night since it was so warm in the restaurant. There were three times I went to grab my glass of water and it was empty. We spent half the time waiting--waiting to hear specials, waiting to get our first glasses of water, waiting to get wine suggestions, waiting to have our order taken, waiting for the check. I think we could have been in and out of there in half the time. My dish was horrible. I ordered what I was hoping was Chapeau's signature dish--the cassoulet. It came out dry as if it had been sitting under a warming lamp for 30 minutes (which would not have surprised me). As we began to eat, I heard no "oh-my-gosh, this is great!" comments nor did I hear any "mmmms". For dessert, the blueberry pastry with creme anglaise tasted like Yoplait blueberry yogurt. The warm chocolate dessert was well-received by those in the party who ordered it. Actually that was the first food-related "ooh-aah" I heard. The best parts of the dinner were the wine that was eventually recommended to us--a Condreau and the decaf cappuccino. The one nice service touch was that one of the waiters went up to Geary to get us a taxi. He would not take a tip and simply asked us to come back again. I wish I could because of his kindness, but that won't be enough for me to return. This was a special occasion since it was the bachelorette party weekend for a good friend of mine. In the end, I was actually embarrassed that I picked this restaurant.

After reading many of the reviews I have been waiting for over a year to eat here. I was preparing myself to meet and be greeted by Phillipe. Upon entering the dining room it was very crowded with tables within arms distance of eachother as expected. Phillipe came charging up to us and greeted us right away looking for a table. We were seated next to the door and I was literally in front of it. A dark curtain is placed in front of the door to prevent people from looking at you while eating. But people would inadvertanly pull the curtain aside to come in and tap me on the shoulder. They probably thought it was a soft couch pillow but that was my fatty back people. Since there were 4 of us we decided to order the 3 dish create your own set menu. For $38 it was a very good deal. We ended up ordering different dishes so we could sample everything. The onion soup and warm brie were very good. I would definitely recommend getting the trio of salmon. It was excellent. We also ordered a large bowl of mussels for the table with pomme frittes. In hind sight we were better off ordering 12 raw oysters. The mussels weren't that great. For dinner I had the bouillabaisse which had a really good flavor. The manatee ended up trading her half eaten monk fish for my 3/4 eaten food. I wasn't going to complain. hahaha. The monk fish was served with a creamy risotto which was on teh creamy side but very good. The monk fish was overcooked, however. It was on the chewy side. But I still devoured it. My sister and her manatee had the prime rib for 2. It was served with bone morrow which I tried for the first time. It was interesting to say the least. But wasn't worth finishing because I don't need extra cholesterol. The prime rib was pretty good but I think it was reheated. It also cooled down fairly quickly. It wasn't the best i've had in the city (No, I don't think House of Prime rib is good). For dessert the Vanilla bean creme brulee is the winner here. It is just as good if not better than Ruth Chris's cremem brulee which is the best I've ever eaten. I am fat and trust me I have eaten my share of creme brulee. The apple tart and chocolate cake were also very good. The napoleon was given a twist served open face with the 3 piece of dough on top of the filling and fruit. On the bottom of the plate was a basil concoction. It made a very interesting combination that worked very well. I was impressed. Overall I ate alot of food because the manatee said I basically ate everyone's appetizer, entree and dessert. As I am sitting here writing this review my stomach is currently resting on my lap. I've had about a dozen dinners at chapeau! over the years, and have consistently found the food to be excellent and the service some of the warmest in the City while maintaining professionalism. They even got me to eat cauliflower -- the amuse bouche one visit was an amazing cauliflower curry . When my dining companion's onion soup was so hot that he was waiting for it to cool while I nibbled my way through my starter, the waiter checked in to make sure there wasn't something wrong with the soup. Too few waiters take the time to do small things like this, but it creates a memorable dining experience. The chef/owner greets diners on their arrival, and will job down the sidewalk a bit to bid you farewell. Looking forward to their taking over of the Clementine space as well -- it might make it possible to stop in and grab a table, which is nearly impossible at the always bustling current location.

I heard such great things about this place from other yelpers as well as Zagat, but I wasn't that amazed by the place. My friend and I went last week and we thought it was alright. They do maximize the little space they are given which causes the place to be very packly tight and loud. We decided to go for the 3 course $39 package but in retrospect, I would have just paid for each part individually since I ended up having the onion soup (one of the less expensive first course options), then I had the osso buco with noodles, and then the orange soup for dessert. The onion soup was good, I was worried, since it was French, that it would be salty but it was great. Next was the osso buco - it was good, but I have had better. It was very salty, too. My friend had the bouillabaisse and it was very very salty! We almost couldn't eat our main courses due to the salt but since we didn't want to be rude, we plowed onto dessert. The only shining moment for my friend from the meal was when her Profiterolles came. She inhaled them! I decided to go lighter and had the orange soup concoction. It was ok, interesting at best. The orange soup in the martini glass would have been fine but it had some odd green mint jelly at the bottom which ruined the orange for me. It did come with a side of orange souffle of some sort which was good. When we left our meal, knowing we weren't coming back anytime soon and needing to drink a lot of water afterwards to quench our thirsts, the chef/owner came running down the street after us to hug and kiss us goodbye, that was a nice touch.

Yum! This place is great! Very small and cozy but certainly works for groups. I came here recently with my monthly supper club and I'm still thinking about how fabulous the creme brulee tasted. So much for Ron's review.  But having been to Chapeau about 15 times over the years, I have to say that for the money, Chapeau has, hands down, the best French bistro experience. Yes, it's out in the foggy sticks of the Richmond, and you'll be surrounded by hefty white haired matrons, but the food, especially the meats, which is Phillipe's forte, is on par with many of the much more expensive establishments downtown. In French style, Phillipe is hugely gregarious and at first, it might seem a bit offputting. But after a while, you realize that he's the real deal. More than once he chased out after us to say goodbye, and he always has an excellent wine suggestion, no matter the price point. For many it may not be worth the trip to the Richmond, but those that make it are rarely disappointed. A perfect spot if you're headed back from the GG bridge, it's dark and foggy, and the hunger for a dry French champagne and crisp frites suddenly seems to rise inside of you. Make a right on Clement and find Phillipe. He'll welcome you and feed you well.
My wife and I are both French and we liked very much this restaurant. The food is perhaps not the best or the most sophisticated French food you might have in SF (we don't know yet, since we moved to SF not too long ago) but without a doubt it was excellent! The selection of wine is very good (we got an amazing bottle of Cahors) and the service is pretty good too. If you get the chance to chat a little with Chef-owner Philippe Gardelle, you will soon realize that he's really passionate about his work. You will for sure appreciate that monsieur Gardelle also deeply cares about his customers, greeting everyone coming in, and running after people in the streets to say goodbye. The only 2 things I did not like too much are the so-so interior decoration and the loudness of the room (even if it is relatively small). Yet, because food and wine were really excellent and because the Chef is so committed to transform what could only be a nice dinner into great experience, I highly recommend Chapeau!
Great French bistro fare with a Californian twist all packaged in a neighborhood restaurant. One of my favorite French bistros in all the various cities I've lived and one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. The prix fixe menus are deals ($35 for 3-course that you pick and choose from the a la carte menu; there's also a 4-course). Besides the delicious dishes, the personal attention of the proprietors, Philippe and Ellen Gardelle, throughout the meal add to the neighborhood feel of the restaurant. For example, on a recent weekday night, there were 6 of us for a relatively late (8:30p) dinner (I made reservations a week in advance and only 5:45p or 8:30p or later were available). The table was ready for us when we arrived and Philippe ushered us to it. During the meal, one of the appetisers that arrived was not one we had ordered, so the waiter quickly went to correct the order but still left the original and said it was on the house (it was the absolutely delicious grilled tiger prawns and scallops). Philippe also has the habit of trying the wines with you if you ask him to recommend something. Talk about standing by your recommendations! After the meal, Philippe bid us good-bye (yes, faire la bise to the ladies). While Ron D.'s comment about the many waiters is true, I think it works for Chapeau (there doesn't seem to be confusion) and keeps the mood fluid, with someone always ready to fill a glass or answer questions.Notes: Definitely make reservations. And the restaurant space, while bright and cozy, is small, tables are set close to each other, and typically full of people, so don't expect a lot of quiet.
this review is long overdue. i've been here a few times, and each time was just as good as the last (if not a bit better). the food is what you'd expect it to be: delicious and indulgent. i usually get the duck confit, duck breast (i really love duck), and the vanilla bean creme brulee whenever i eat here; but last time i did the duck breast was not on the menu =( nonetheless dinner was still excellent. phillipe and his wife are just darling. great wait staff and service. nothing to complain about at all!
Besides the ho-hum decor and the tight dinning quarters, this place was a real treat. Everything on the menu looked great; what we ended up ordering turned out to be absolutely delightful (halibut & fillet). The best part of the meal was definitely the warm chocolate cake...
What a wonderful surprise. We and another couple have been out trying new, highly touted restaurants--with positive--but not knock-your-socks-off results. So maybe older is better? Chapeau! is a multi-star gem, and I have already booked a table for the return trip. While the place looks like it could be stuffy, the staff, though formal enough, couldn't be friendlier. They strike an unusual balance between creating a special atmosphere, while putting you at ease and offering advice and knowledge about the food and wine. Chef Philippe Gardellclearly enjoys working the front of the house, from his personal welcome to each guest, to pouring the wine, to his final au revoir at the door. And all of this wonderful ambiance is enhanced by the food. A delicate corn soup with crab, a baked brie, goat cheese galette, heirloom tomatoe salade, were among the flavorful starters. Though the menu is based in classical french cooking, it is lightened and freshened with subtle flavors. The duck breast was moist and tender, the bacon-wrapped pork loin was mouthwatering and the vegeterian terrine sparkling with lively tomatoe, corn, and several other crisp tastes. Two of us had the 3 course menu ($38)--so that we shared two deserts--which featured the warm chocolate cake with rum raisin ice cream and caramel. That about put us over the top for this rich evening. Each portion was more than adequate, and we all considered this a great value. They also have a terrific wine list that highlights good choices under $30. I can't wait to try it again.
Amazing little place to go for French food. We went for the first time this past month. On a Thursday night with a 8:30 seating, the restaurant was still packed.  Nice decor, wall-to-wall tables make it a cozy, but comfortable fit. Definitely not a place to go for a quiet candlelit dinner, but if melt in your mouth food and good service is what you are looking for, you can't miss. They also have a nice wine list.

I went to Chapeau! last night on a Tuesday. It's like transporting you to France, what a great experience. Philippe greets you as you enter and makes you feel like you are part of the family the whole time. They do not rush you at all and when we left around 10:30pm, people were still talking amongst themselves, which reminds me so much of restaurants in Europe. I started with the corn soup, it was amazing, although very creamy so it was a little filling. We also had the salmon which was very tender, nothing special though. I had the Salmon as a main dish and my friend had the Halibut. The Salmon was cooked perfectly but I think the sauce it came with was a little overpowering, but a fine dish overall. The Halibut was definitely better with the sauce perfectly matching the delicate flavors of the fish. We ordered a bottle of Chateneuf-du-Pape from Grenache grapes which he highly recommended (it was around $70) but we wanted to splurge. It was truly amazing, very balanced and fruity, I definitely recommend it. For dessert we had the apple tart which was very good and also the Creme Brule which was amazing, highly recommend it. Overall I give it 4 stars for the food, 5 stars for the wine, service and personal touch that Phillipe gives the place.
We finally had time to dine here after hearing so many good things about this place over the years. The service certainly sets the standard and ranks among the best. Half an hour late during the dinner hour, we were seated immediately without incident. Greetings included a personal one from Chef Philippe Gardelle! What can one say? The place is hard to find in the evening and night hours. The exterior is very low key in a great residential neighborhood, yet once inside, it is inviting, cozy yet lively. Our dining experience included wrapped pork loin and scallops, both presented well and cooked to perfection! An excellent french onion, as well as a squash soup complemented the meal, as did our desserts - which literally disappeared in a flash. Oh, by the way, the pricing here is excellent! Several prix fix options - from around $38 and up. Great food, wonderful atmosphere, professional staff, and Chef Philippe personally greeting and sending us off made for an impeccable experience.

chapeau is the quintessential san francisco neighborhood restaurant. the place is small and non-descript, and its on a residential strip of clement. as you walk in, it becomes evident that chapeau has build up a loyal clientele.... how many french restaurants can you go to and see two old chinese men enjoying a french meal, or a family with kids out celebrating a birthday, or have the chef personally greet every guest with a "bonjour/bonsoir". no, this isnt a place to be seen, this is a place to go enjoy a good homecooked french meal. i guess you can say its quaint. the food is very homestyle french, nothing outrageous, nothing over-reaching.... just good french food, very satisfying, very comforting. if you get the prix fix, then two of you can get out of there for under $80 with a glass of wine each, tax and tip included. does a restaurant like chapeau deserve five stars? i pondered this, and for me its simple. chapeau is what it is, and it does it very well.
